dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A MAN'S HAND, hardworking, rough, lights twigs under a ke Predawn light trickles through the tin walls onto well wo farming tools...hoe, pick, axe, a yoke for an ox. Animist totems and charms hang. We are in a typical Mende FARMER' HUT. Except for the ENGLISH SCHOOLBOOKS on a shelf. The HAND that lit the kettle takes the books off the shel and gently nudges a 14-year-old BOY awake with them. The boy, DIA is his name, groans in sleepy protest. SOLOMON VANDY smiles down at his son.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: (in Mende; subtitled) Don't want to be late. The boy sits up, half asleep. Sleepily pulls a shirt over his head. His English is more schooled than his father's.

dialogues.speaker: DIA
dialogues.text: (in Mende; subtitled) English boys go to school every day? Solomon fills a tin cup of powdered milk. He is a man mar by quiet patience, in the worn trousers and white cotton shirt of a Mende farmer. He hands the cup to the boy.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: {in Mende; subtitled) Yes, they do.

dialogues.speaker: DIA
dialogues.text: (in Mende; subtitled) Not every day.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: (in Mende; subtitled) Every day. Just like you. So you can become a doctor. Not walk behind an ox like your father. The boy catches his MOTHER's eye as she breast-feeds his INFANT BROTHER, His twelve-year old sister, N'YANDA, snug with them. She sticks her tongue out at her brother.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don't worry. She will be joining you next year. JASSIE sends both her men a kiss as they head out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Mende, subtitled) Be careful on the road. Solomon gives his wife an "I know" look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solomon and Dia emerge into the early light. Their hut is in a hamlet amidst cassava patches eeked out of the jungl

dialogues.speaker: DIA
dialogues.text: Don't want to be a doctor. (off Solomon's look) I want to be President. Solomon puts his arm around him. They head into the field

dialogues.speaker: CREDITS END
dialogues.text: Solomon stands stock still, sensing something ... A few chickens flit away without crowing. The oxen are skittish

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: Go back inside... NOW! Dia is confused. Solomon pushes him into the hut as grinn TEENAGE REBELS appear. One wears a Tupac t-shirt. He rake everything with AK-47 FIRE. Huts. Animals. People. Solomon dives to the ground. VILLAGERS run screaming. Chickens squawk, oxen bray. A rumble. Two mud-splattered PICK-UP TRUCKS with sawed-off roofs crash through the bru full of R.U.F. REBELS, who quickly jump off -- shouting, wielding machetes and automatic rifles, BANDOLIERS OF AMM criss-crossed on their bare chests, GRENADES on their bel Solomon cowers amidst the gunfire, looks around frantical Men and boys are being rounded up. Huts set on fire. Suddenly he is yanked up as two REBELS pull him away-- Jassie exits their hut, infant in her arms, mad with fear

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solomon! He shouts back. Only one word.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: Run! She doesn't. She just stands there screaming his name. No Solomon's son and daughter come out of the hut.

dialogues.speaker: PAPA
dialogues.text: Solomon, the rifle choking him, as he's dragged away.

dialogues.speaker: RUN
dialogues.text: Jassie grabs her son's arm. He resists, staring in anguis at his father. But she tugs at him. And with the two youn children in tow, they join others. Running. Solomon watches them disappear into the bush.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE NEXT MOMENT
dialogues.text: he's rounded up with the OTHER MALES. Only a few able-bod among them. Most are old, skinny men and terrified boys. REBELS prod them with rifles, making them form a line. Al under the watchful sunglasses of an R.U.F. COLONEL. The FIRST VILLAGER is shoved to his knees in front of a t stump. A muscle-bound, SHIRTLESS REBEL with a gleaming AX struts over, his eyes glazed from palm wine and marijuana A second rebel grabs the village man's HAND and places it the stump. The man pulls his hand away. Tupac t-shirt put the Ak-47 to his head. The choice is clear. Your head or your hands. The villager tries to scramble away. RAT-A-TAT! Bullet through his head. The choice is made for him. The next man in line is made to kneel at the stump.

dialogues.speaker: TUPAC T-SHIRT
dialogues.text: Long sleeve or short sleeve? The other stoned rebels find this hilarious. ON SOLOMON, witnessing his mutilation as terrified WAILS rise around him. The discarded limb is thrown into a bag. The next in line, A STRONG YOUNG MAN, is pushed to the st  10

dialogues.speaker: R.U.F. COLONEL
dialogues.text: Not him. He can work. The STRONG YOUNG MAN is herded into a waiting truck. Next comes AN OLD MAN. Shaking, he offers his withered hand. ON SOLOMON. The “crunch" of the axe bores into his soul. The old man is lifted to his feet in clinical shock. Both his forearms end in bloody stumps.

dialogues.speaker: R.U.F. COLONEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You are the messenger. Spread the word. Guv'ment say da future is in your hands? We say R.U.F. is da future. Revolution is at hand. Solomon is next. He closes his eyes as his hand is placed on the tree stump slick with blood. The Colonel looks him over. Motions the henchmen to stop.

dialogues.speaker: R.U. F. COLONEL
dialogues.text: You will need your hands. Solomon is herded into the truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A seaplane soars above the bush. At the stick, DANNY ARCH He has seen more in his thirty years than most people hav seen in a lifetime of watching bad television. He scans the landscape then dips toward the estuary of a broad river, eventually splashing to a stop.

dialogues.speaker: NEARBY, ON THE SANDY BANK 9
dialogues.text: Sitting in a lawn chair is COMMANDER RAMBO, a twenty year old R.U.F. fighter with a goatee, wrap-around sunglasses, and a Bob Marley t-shirt. Arrayed behind him, several BODYGUARDS cradle automatic weapons while eating m&m's. A huge BOOM BOX throbs out Tupac's "If I Die 2Nite.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FAWAZ, a thin Lebanese man, sits beside Archer and eyes t rebels waiting on the riverbank. Murmurs a prayer in Arab

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Say one for me, my friend. Archer closes his eyes for a moment, then checks the clip his 9mm Sig-Sauer before tucking it into his belt and pul his shirt-tails over it. Takes a deep breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Archer wades in and approaches the group. Imagine teenage on a corner in Bed-Sty carrying AK-47's. Their menace is palpable even as they laugh and pass around a big spliff.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: You are Colonel Zero?

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER RAMBO
dialogues.text: I am Commander Rambo.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: What happened to Colonel Zero? No response. A few of the rebels giggle.

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER RAMBO
dialogues.text: He was not committed to the revolution. You are here to help us in our struggle against the oppressor.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: I'm here to do business. They eye each other in silence.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You have something for me.

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER RAMBO
dialogues.text: First you will show me what you have brought.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: No. First you will pay for them. Rambo looks at him with dead eyes. Archer looks back with eyes equally dead. A nasty stand-off. Until Rambo hands him a small, filthy cloth SACK. Archer tips a few rough diamonds into his hand.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (in Krio; subtitled) This is not what was agreed.

dialogues.speaker: COMANDER RAMBO
dialogues.text: (in Krio; subtitled) Maybe I will take the weapons and give you nothing. Archer closes his eyes again, looks back at the seaplane. The cargo door SLIDES OPEN, revealing the muzzle of a M-1 Assault Weapon. Fawaz racks its slide. In response, the Rebels slide the bolts on their weapons.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: (in Krio; subtitled) Maybe I'll just do my business with the government. At least the oppressor pays his bills. He turns and starts back toward the plane.

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER RAMBO
dialogues.text: Wait... Wait... Rambo smiles as if it has all been a joke. He reaches int a rusty coffee can and pulls out a huge handful of diamon

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER RAMBO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is what you want? Here... So many, I don't know what to do with them all. He gestures for Archer to hold out his hands and pours hi handful.

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER
dialogues.text: You bring a satellite dish next time, yah? I want to watch NYPD Blue.

dialogues.speaker: MOMENTS LATER 11A
dialogues.text: As the seaplane takes off, we see the rebels unloading cr of RPGs with Ukranian markings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fawaz gleefully examines their haul.

dialogues.speaker: PAWAZ
dialogues.text: I'm buying an electronics store. Sit on my ass all day, drink sweet tea and watch dvd's. How about it, Danny? Archer closes his eyes for a moment. He is free.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Fly the plane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An open pit alluvial mine carved beside a jungle river. M and boys toil knee deep in muddy water. They dig with the hands, shoveling silt into wooden troughs. All under the watchful eyes and guns of R.U.F. REBELS who stand on the banks passing a fat joint rolled in newspaper. Meanwhile, their leader -- CAPTAIN POISON -- spouts twist revolutionary dogma to the diggers:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Freetown guv-a-ment and their white masters have raped your land to feed their greed! We have freed you! No more slave and master here! We are all brothers! Solomon, his back straining under the weight of a circula sieve, pauses to wipe sweat from his eyes. He's prodded with a rifle, looks up into the fierce FACE of Captain Po

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN POISON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Back to work! Your work is your liberation! Work harder! Dig harder! Solomon turns back to his sieve. ANOTHER DIGGER, peers in his sieve, plucks something out, holds it up in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: DIGGER
dialogues.text: Kunaa! All work stops. A rebel comes over. The digger hands him the tiny, milky crystal. A diamond. Without a word, the Commander wraps the stone in a piece of paper. As work resumes, Solomon watches the piece of paper hande off to a RUNNER, who runs it over to the SAME COMMANDER, sits under the shade of a palm frond umbrella reading a Hustler magazine. He stuffs the diamond into his shirt po without even looking at it. Across from Solomon, a 3RD DIGGER glances around. Furtive picks a stone from the sieve and slips it into his mouth. He meets Solomon's eyes. Solomon looks away, keeps workin When he becomes aware of Captain Poison's eyes on him. Solomon tries to shake off the eyes by shaking the sieve. Captain Poison remains staring at him, intently. Then, ca walks over to the 3rd digger with the diamond in his mout AND SHOOTS HIM, at point blank range. Everything stops. Poison turns back to Solomon.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN POISON
dialogues.text: You. Bring him out. Solomon puts down his sieve. Looks at the BODY floating next to him, turning the muddy water red ...

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Dear Jassie. I cannot write well enough to put in a letter all the thoughts in my head.  14 15 16 17 18 19

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solomon devours a meager portion of rice gruel in a tin c Others sleep in their fetid clothes on the ground.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Even if I could, my guards would not let me send it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solomon sits shivering, looking out at the guards on watc Beyond, a lit TENT where rebels drink and shout back at a satellite TV playing, "Who Wants To Be a Millionaire.”

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I do not know where you are. I do not even know where I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jassie and the children are among a group of homeless Men Dia carries the infant. Hearing trucks coming, they scatt into the bush. An R.U.F convoy roars past. After a moment they return to the road.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: I only know that my thoughts fly over the mountains to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solomon lays there. Eyes open in a living nightmare.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: I will find you, Jassie. I£ it takes my whole life. We will be together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A high pass. Misty peaks in the distance. A BRILLIANT RED SHAPE comes into view - the bright headdress of a HAUSA SHEPHERD. He carries a spear as he leads a herd of GOATS, bells clinking around their necks. Picking up the rear is Archer, checking a handheld GPS. H SATELLITE PHONE buzzes...

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: We're two clicks from the strip. What've you got?

dialogues.speaker: EXT/INT. TWIN ENGINE TURBO PROP
dialogues.text: Piloted by Fawaz. He speaks into his SAT phone, worriedly looking down on the dense jungle canopy.  20

dialogues.speaker: FAWAZ
dialogues.text: ...Company.

dialogues.text: Sure enough, over the hill, comes an armed patrol of ECOM SOLDIERS. The TROOP LEADER approaches Archer.

dialogues.speaker: TROOP LEADER
dialogues.text: Papers. Archer fishes out identification. Hands it over.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Elliot Smith, National Geographic.

dialogues.speaker: TROOP LEADER
dialogues.text: You are crossing into Liberia.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: I have a letter from the Minister of Interior and a Liberian visa as well. (as the Captain studies the papers) Doing a story on the Hausa who, as you know, are allowed to cross the border to get to grazing grounds. Up above, the tiny Plane drones past. The troop leader glances up, then at Archer, who courteously offers an uno pack of cigarettes from his shirt pocket.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ever read National Geographic? The troop leader ignores him, walks over toa goat and run his hands down the goat's back, under its chin. His hands part a tuft of hair -- revealing a surgically straight li of STITCHES in the goat's skin. Archer feels the shape of the 9mm under his shirt, looks around at the rifles. Too many of them. The troop leader takes out a KNIFE and cuts into the stit The goat squeals a little and kicks angrily. From under t goat's skin, he takes a dozen small, rough DIAMONDS. The troop leader draws his -45 on Archer.

dialogues.speaker: TROOP LEADER
dialogues.text: You are under arrest for smuggling.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Now you listen here, my man. JI ama good friend of Minister Somora. He will not be pleased you have interfered with his business.  21 10. Clearly the name of Minister Somora carries some weight.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know who I am, don't you? What Iam...? I don't think you want to mess with me. Or my friends, eh? (changes his tack) How about I just look the other way and you pocket one or two of those stones. Buy something nice for the wife. Or maybe the mistress, eh? (re the shepherds) Who's going to tell? Them? The shepherds look, uncertain, from Archer to the soldier

dialogues.speaker: TROOP LEADER
dialogues.text: No. The troop leader FIRES. One of the shepherds falls dead. The other is cut down as he tries to flee. The leader fro at Archer, whose world has suddenly turned upside down.

dialogues.speaker: TROOP LEADER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We will go back to Freetown and ask Minister Somora how he wishes to thank his business associate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Archer is handcuffed to a chair. A large, rotund FIGURE enters, silhouetted against the bright windows.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Mr. Minister, there seems to have been a terrible misunderst-- SOMORA BACKHANDS him. Archer's head rocks backwards.

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER SOMORA
dialogues.text: I thought we were friends,

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: You're right, you're right... I took a little initiative but-- Another SLAP.

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER SOMORA
dialogues.text: Have I not been good to you?

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: (licks his split lip) Absolutely. And I was planning to cut you in. Haven't I always been--  22 ll. This SLAP knocks Archer's chair backwards to the cement. lies there for a moment. Somora looms over him.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look... if you wanted to kill me, you would've done it already. So what is it you want me to do? Somora smiles. One of his teeth has a tiny diamond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SECRETARY GENERAL of the UN addresses a a full ASSEMB

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY GENERAL
dialogues.text: We propose then to prohibit the direct or indirect import of all rough diamonds from conflict zones to the territory of Member States. He looks at the front row where TWO MEN IN SAVILLE ROW SU sit among the Representatives. One is sandy-haired, 40, h name is SIMMONS. He serves a distinguished-looking older man, 60, with a shock of white hair. His name is DE WENTE

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY GENERAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: As we know, these stones are only a small percentage of the legitimate diamond industry -- whose trade is crucial to the economies of several emerging nations, and I applaud their support of such a ban. The well-dressed diamond industry reps smile back.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: in a reception hall. The Diamond industry REPS and WIVES mingle with UN MEMBERS and other DIGNITARIES. US AMBASSAD WALKER approaches De Wente, holds out his hand.

dialogues.speaker: AMBASSADOR WALKER
dialogues.text: Mister De Wente... Judd Walker--

dialogues.speaker: DE WENTE
dialogues.text: Ambassador. Good to finally meet you.

dialogues.speaker: AMBASSADOR WALKER
dialogues.text: You don't spend much time this side of the Atlantic.

dialogues.speaker: DE WENTE
dialogues.text: I'm hoping to change that. Perhaps with your help.  24 12.

dialogues.speaker: AMBASSADOR WALKER
dialogues.text: Mr. De Wente, I'm afraid I don't have much faith in any industry's ability to police itself.

dialogues.speaker: DE WENTE
dialogues.text: I assure you, sir, we both want the same thing. These 'conflict' stones put the legitimacy of our entire business at risk. De Wente's young blonde WIFE appears at his side. It's ha to decide which is more beautiful, the woman or the two- million-dollar DIAMOND NECKLACE she's wearing.

dialogues.speaker: DE WENTE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Darling... This is Ambassador Walker.

dialogues.speaker: DE WENTE'S WIFE
dialogues.text: How nice to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: DE WENTE
dialogues.text: (his arm around her) It's my belief, Ambassador, that diamonds should be associated with romance and beauty. Not warfare. Don't you agree? How can the Ambassador not be dazzled? From the glitterin diamonds, we cut to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solomon works in the muddy water, his eyes transfixed by sparkling reflections of the river and the swaying trees that seem so unaffected by the brutality beneath.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Dear Jassie. How can it be that one stone is worth more than another? Solomon wills himself back to the soul-killing work. Suddenly, a WATER PUMP BREAKS -- gushing like a fire hose knocking over Solomon and several diggers. Solomon's siev is swept down river. He swims after the SIEVE. Grabs it, sloshing his way back, when he stops... There, underwater, by the riverbank, is something SHINY E to reflect the sun. As the silt washes away, the object remains underwater. A ROCK of a startling pink color. Solomon blinks down at it. The DIAMOND sparkles up at him  25 26 13.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: And how can a thing that comes from our mother the earth be so beautiful as to make people want to kill? Solomon looks around. Rebel guards are fixing the pump, shouting at diggers to get back to work. Solomon scoops the diamond into his sieve, covers it with silt. His heart is pounding as he wades back to the bank.

dialogues.speaker: REBEL GUARD
dialogues.text: You daydreaming? Get back to work! Solomon nods. Quickly submerges his silt-heaped sieve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solomon overturns the sieve. His BARE FOOT catches the diamond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solomon raises his hand to get the guards‘ attention. He clutches his abdomen, painfully.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: I must go badly. (pleading) Can't hold it in, boss. The guard motions him out. Solomon climbs out, sliding hi second foot carefully. He shuffles to the edge of the jun

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN POISON
dialogues.text: Stop. Solomon freezes. Poison searches Solomon. Starting with his hair, his ears, nose. Squeezing his cheeks to see int his mouth. Frisking his pants, unrolling his cuffs.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN POISON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Lift your foot. Solomon lifts his right foot. They check between his toes

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN POISON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The other. Solomon, looking into Poison's eyes, lifts his left foot. Poison checks between the toes. Satisfied.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN POISON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Make it quick. CLOSE ON SOLOMON’'S FOOT, as he lowers it. The toes curl into the soft muddy earth, obviously retrieving something  27 28 29 14.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Solomon squats behind a fallen tree, he eyes the guard through the broad leaves. Quickly, his toes release the muddy gob under his foot. H rubs the mud off it. It's raw beauty is almost unnatural. He glances back to make sure he is unobserved and then ri the cuff off his pants. A CLICK at his head. Solomon slowly looks up ... into the BARREL OF A COLT .45

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN POISON
dialogues.text: Give it to me. Solomon doesn't move. What difference does it make? He. awaits the crack of the gun, when: A MORTAR ROUND COMES SCREAMING OUT OF THE JUNGLE. THE EXPLOSION knocks Solomon to the ground. MORE MORTARS. ECOMOG government troops appear, firing automatic weapons. Solomon scrambles over to Poison's ble body, removes the MACHETE from the belt. As shrapnel shreds the greenery, he furiously digs with t machete. Wraps the DIAMOND in his TORN GREEN CUFF and pla it in the hole. When he is STRUCK IN THE HEAD BY A RIFLE BUTT. He falls. ECOMOG SOLDIERS are shouting at him in Mende. Solomon realizes he still holds the machete, lets it drop

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: Don't shoot! I am not R.U.F! Around him ECOMOG soldiers beat the rebel prisoners with sticks -- in the distance, others are EXECUTED at random.

dialogues.text: A convoy of MILITARY TRUCKS rolls through teeming streets Women walk with baskets on their heads, tribal bells jing around their ankles. "Businessmen" in white suits sip Coc Colas outside a hotel. A UN helicopter circles overhead.

dialogues.text: Solomon sits chained to other rebel prisoners. He's never been to a city, never seen so many people. It's overwhelm  30 is. He stares at the BEGGARS who run alongside. War orphans, the same age as his own son. He searches every face

dialogues.text: Archer looks up from a game of solitaire as REBEL PRISONE are marched past his dank cell.

dialogues.speaker: REBEL
dialogues.text: R.U.F. is coming! Operation Chop Hands! Get ready, my brothers! Archer turns his attention back to his game as the cell d next to his is opened and Solomon is thrown in.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: I am not R.U.F. My name is Solomon Vandy! I ama farmer! Archer assesses him. Solomon gives him a hard stare. MORE PRISONERS are brought in, one carried on a stretcher A bandage covers half his face. But when he turns his hea we see that it's Captain Poison. Solomon turns away. Poison lifts his head, squinting through the CELL BARS.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN POISON
dialogues.text: What did you do with it? Solomon doesn't acknowledge Poison.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN POISON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm talking to you! You hear me!? Where is the diamond!? Archer pricks up his ears, but goes on playing solitaire.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN POISON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A pink diamond. I saw you take it!! Archer's hand, flipping over a card, stops. Listening intently now but careful not to show it.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: You are mad. I do not know you.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN POISON
dialogues.text: I saw it with my own eyes!! Poison reaches into his sweat stained shirt, an IVORY CHA from around his neck. Holds it up for all to see.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN POISON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This big! Biggest I have ever seen!! Solomon just shakes his head, absurdly.  31 16. BUT ARCHER'S EYES...are on the ivory charm, even as he ke playing solitaire. Poison calls to the guards.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN POISON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I will give a thousand dollars to the man who cuts it out of him! These words do something to Solomon. He stands and rips o his shirt. Then his torn pants. Everything. Until he stan completely naked, facing Captain Poison through the bars.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: Where is a diamond? Do you see a diamond!? You devils have taken my family. My home. Everything! Here! Look! What is left!? What is left!? If there is a diamond, then you are the one who has taken it!! Poison lifts his upper body from the stretcher.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN POISON
dialogues.text: Liar! He's a LIAR! The army guards have had enough. They silence Poison with rifle butt to the face. As they drag him away, they give Solomon a “got my eye on you, too" glare. Archer lays out a new hand of solitaire. His eyes move to Solomon, then away. He's heard all he has to. Solomon begins putting his clothes back on. The fury stil in his eyes. Through the bars, he gives Archer a final gl Archer turns away, just keeps playing cards. But then ... ever so carefully ... he picks out the ACE O DIAMONDS. Folds it in half. He gets up and goes to his cell door. Waits until a PRISON GUARD passes by.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Excuse me, brother. Think you could get a message to Minister Somora? The prison guard sees the PACK OF CIGARETTES - and the fo card - that Archer holds through the bars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Archer walks out into the street, blinks in the sunlight.

dialogues.speaker: ACROSS THE STREET
dialogues.text: is observed in the REARVIEW MIRROR of a parked car by a m with a reddish crewcut. His name is JOOST. FAWAZ appears and hands Archer his hat.  17.

dialogues.speaker: FAWAZ
dialogues.text: How on earth did you get them to let you go?

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: There's a farmer in there. He might've found a pink.

dialogues.speaker: FAWAZ
dialogues.text: And what? You told Somora you'd get hold of it?

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: I need to contact our friends in London.

dialogues.speaker: FAWAZ
dialogues.text: I thought we were working for Somora.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Who needs Somora if the pink is real? Archer can tell that Fawaz is holding something back.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ~-What?

dialogues.speaker: FAWAZ
dialogues.text: London wants nothing more to do with you. Fawaz hands him a newspaper clipping.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: (reads) "The arrest in Sierra Leone on June One of Daniel Archer, former mercenary and smuggler with ties to the De Wente diamond cartel highlights the trafficking problem blah blah blah..." (crumples it) Fucking hell. He starts off down the street, calling over his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: His name is Solomon something... Mortgage the plane if you have to -- just get him out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dripping wet from a shower, Archer is working the phone.  33 34 35 18.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: (on the phone) see Well, can you tell Mr. De Wente Danny Archer called?..... Archer. A...R...

dialogues.speaker: JUMP CUT
dialogues.text: Archer smokes his tenth cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: {on the phone) What time did he say he'd be back?

dialogues.speaker: JUMP CUT -
dialogues.text: Archer pounds his fist into a wall.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yes, he definitely knows what this is in regard to........ Yes.... Yes......... I've been holding.... In frustration, he throws the phone across the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Archer leaves the shabby hotel, having changed clothes. H is mobbed by the inevitable swarm of beggars who call him name...."°Arrr-cherrr, Arrr-cherr."

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Piss off. He pushes his way past without a trace of compassion.

dialogues.speaker: MEANWHILE
dialogues.text: JOOST, the man we saw surveilling Archer, enters and begi to SEARCH the room, He is professional and brutal -- ripp apart bedding, smashing the phone machine, even slitting carpet into thin strips with a razor blade. It is clear he is looking for something quite small.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every war zone has a place like this. Soldiers, smugglers opportunists of every stripe stand shoulder to shoulder a oo bar. Bad guys and do-gooders, UN workers and eco- backpackers drink overpriced, watered-down liquor, trade gossip, and hook up for desperate expatriate sex. "Sierra Afrique" blends African drums and electric bass. Every now and then, in the distant hills, the muted SOUND AN EXPLOSION and a rising COLUMN OF SMOKE. No one pays an attention. There is serious drinking to be done.  19. As Archer shoulders his way past, we OVERHEAR brief snipp of conversation. A Nigerian peacekeeper hits on a tipsy blond Red Cross Worker.

dialogues.speaker: PEACEKEEPER
dialogues.text: This place is nothing but hustlers and dopers. I will take you back to Nigeria. Show you the real Africa.

dialogues.speaker: RED CROSS WORKER
dialogues.text: Is that so? He whispers in her ear and she giggles. Next to them, two SUITS from the Chemical Bank:

dialogues.speaker: SUIT
dialogues.text: ~- Fifty thousand in cash. And that's just to get a meeting with him.

dialogues.speaker: SUIT
dialogues.text: The only difference between the crooks who run the country and the R.U.F.-- The AFRICAN BARTENDER (M'ED) serves their drinks.

dialogues.speaker: AFRICAN BARTENDER, (M'ED)
dialogues.text: --is fifty miles. Word on de street dey took Marampa yesterday. He points up into the hills where another explosion rises

dialogues.speaker: AFRICAN BARTENDER, (M'ED)
dialogues.text: Time to reconfirm dose flight reservations, maybe. Archer approaches the bar. His arrival is cause for sever whispered remarks among those in the know.

dialogues.speaker: AFRICAN BARTENDER, (M'ED)
dialogues.text: How de body, Mr. Archer?

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Every day above ground, M'ed... (looks to the hills) Your rebel friends planning to visit us one of these days?

dialogues.speaker: AFRICAN BARTENDER, (M'ED)
dialogues.text: Oh, I 'magine dey come do some shopping verrry soon. He laughs darkly. Archer salutes him with his drink. Near an ATTRACTIVE WOMAN taps her swizzle stick on the bar as Oasis' "Party Like It's '99" ends:  20.

dialogues.speaker: RADIO ANNOUNCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: This is the Voice of America. Another good day on Wall Street, the Dow Jones up twenty-five points, the Nasdag up forty... In the White House, President Clinton again defended his relationship with Monica Lewinsky-- The woman near Archer speaks up:

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Are you listening to this? The world's falling apart and all we hear about is Blowjobgate... Archer turns to MADDY BOWEN. Maddy's a 'handful' whose be belies the kind of fierce intelligence that sends most me running for the door. Archer likes what he sees.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: When's the last time the world wasn't falling apart?

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: Oh. A realist. Been there, done that, got the t-shirt. Is that it?

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Danny Archer.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: Maddy Bowen.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: (appraising her) American.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: Guilty.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Americans usually are. Maddy raises an eyebrow. He plays rough. She likes it.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: Ouch.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Don't tell me, you're here to make a difference.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: And you're here to make a buck. Archer smiles. It's been a long time since he was interes  21.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: See that guy? Government minister caught pocketing disaster relief money. Bad move, know why? Wasn't giving a big enough cut to his boss... (points nearby) That one...? Sells AK-47's to the rebels and waits for a cease-fire to buy ‘em at a discount, then after the fighting starts again, sells them back at a profit.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: And your point is?

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: The point is, it's Africa. There is no point. You want another?

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: Vodka. Rocks. Archer catches Med's eye -- who nods approvingly at Maddy

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: M'ed. Same again.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: You were born here?

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Rhodesia.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: You were there during the war? Must have been rough.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: (offering nothing) Loved it.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: And you're a smuggler.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Am 1?

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: Somehow I don't take you as the UNICEF type. Archer just smiles.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I was going to say 'soldier-of- fortune' but it's such a cliche.  36 22.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: How about hired gun. People seem to like that one.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: Diamonds?

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: What if I told you I was a missionary.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: (laughs) For De Wente?

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: It's not just rude to ask those kind of questions, Ms. Bowen, it's also dangerous.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: I'll take my chances. (leans closer) So... tell me about blood diamonds. And then, suddenly, Archer gets it. His face turns to sto

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: ..-You're a journalist.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: That's right. Archer stands up from his stool.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Piss off. He throws some money onto the bar. Maddy follows him out.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: De Wente Diamonds closed its buying offices here to avoid U.N. sanctions. But they're using cut-outs to buy stones from the rebels on the cheap. That way nobody accuses them of profiting from the war --which they clearly are.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: I'm shocked.  37 38 39 40 23.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: You got popped trying to go free- lance, so they cut you loose and let you rot in jail. (grabs him) Don't you want a chance to get even? He keeps walking.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey, wait a second. She grabs his arm. Moves closer.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (the slightest sexual promise) Help me out here... He can't help but give a bitter laugh.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Maddy, right? (she nods) ... Usually I liked to be kissed before I get fucked. He walks off, leaving her to the inevitable swarm of begg

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Archer walks in and sees the wreckage of his life.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE BATHROOM
dialogues.text: Archer stares at himself in the remains of his mirror. He opens a bottle of vodka and chugs it.

dialogues.speaker: A FLASH CUT
dialogues.text: South African Security Forces BREAK DOWN a door and roust sleeping middle-aged ANC supporter from his bed. His wife SCREAMS as Archer puts a bag over the man's head.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO THE BATHROOM
dialogues.text: Archer takes a long pull of vodka and tosses the bottle. With a pliers he grips a false crown atop A BACK TOOTH.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER FLASH CUT
dialogues.text: The Black prisoner is naked, tied to a chair. We do not s what is being done to him. Instead, we study Archer's fac as he watches. 37 38 39 40  41 42 43 44 24.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO THE BATHROOM
dialogues.text: Bright drops of blood drip into the sink. Ignoring the incredible pain, Archer rips out the crown. Into his palm, he taps a bloody ROUGH DIAMOND.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A crowded street of little STOREFRONTS with hand-painted signs of diamonds. Street merchants lick their palms and hiss as Archer passes.

dialogues.speaker: INT, FAST EDDIE'S
dialogues.text: Little more than a corrugated shack. We see Archer haggli and reluctantly accepting less cash than his stone is wor

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joost is waiting in the road, making no attempt to hide.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Joost. JOosT Long time, mate.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: How's Alice?

dialogues.speaker: JOOST
dialogues.text: Well, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Tim must be in college.

dialogues.speaker: JOOST
dialogues.text: Big kids, big problems... you know.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Company's doing well? Joost Can't complain. Eleven wars on the continent, business is brisk. {looks at him) Heard you had a bit of trouble in the bush.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Somora called you. JOOsT Minister Somora and the Colonel are old friends. 41 42 43 44  as 46 47 48 49 25. Joost smiles. Archer takes out a pack of cigarettes, offe one. Joost demurs. Archer pats his pockets for a match.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Got a light? Joost reaches into his pocket, takes out a lighter. As he leans in to light Archer's cigarette--

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Next time the Colonel has a question. All he has to do is ask. He walks away, leaving Joost writhing in the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Archer pays cash for a round-trip ticket to London.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The global nexus of the diamond trade. A cab pulls up and Archer gets out, wearing a suit. ACROSS THE STREET, a small group of PROTESTERS with signs that read, "No Blood Diamonds," and "DTC Funds Torture." One sign has a drawing of a diamond ring on a severed fin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Archer passes through security: fingerprint reader, scann the works. He is buzzed through an ANTI-BALLISTIC DOOR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He glances at the well-lit display cases -- one of which features a replica of the 530-carat "Star of Africa".

dialogues.speaker: A FLAT-SCREEN MONITOR
dialogues.text: plays a Ridley Scott commercial for De Wente diamonds. Romantic. Flashy. A young man proposes to a beautiful blushing girl. An older couple celebrate their anniversar Rappers wearing ‘bling' on the Grammy Awards.

dialogues.speaker: DTC CLERK
dialogues.text: Mister Simmons will see you now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROLAND SIMMON'S office is tasteful and inoffensive. So is Roland Simmons. We last saw him at the UN.  26.

dialogues.speaker: SIMMONS
dialogues.text: Come in. Come in. Tea?

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: No thanks.

dialogues.speaker: SIMMONS
dialogues.text: So. What brings you to London?

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Reg... Spare me. Simmons adjusts the trousers of his bespoke suit. He'd ra talk about anything but business, but if Archer insists:

dialogues.speaker: SIMMONS
dialogues.text: A month ago, officers of this company sat in front of the United Nations and pledged to uphold a ban on “conflict” diamonds. (looks out the window) We are no longer accepting the stones you supply. I'm truly sorry you've come all this way, but our relationship is officially over. Archer looks around. Realizes.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: You're recording this. Simmons smiles. Archer doesn't give a shit. Record this.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're losing your hold on the global market. Big finds in Russia, Canada. You need me more than ever. Simmons glances at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: SIMMONS
dialogues.text: You don't plan to lecture me on the trade, do you?

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: The trade? Oh, that has such a nicer ring to it than “cartel,” "Cartel" is for Columbian drug dealers and oil sheiks. It's so... unbecoming. Archer stands and walks to a FRAMED WALL PHOTO of the distinguished older MAN whom we last saw at the UN.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But since it's just the two of us, Reg, let's cut the bullshit. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You've got eight-billion-dollars- worth of stones gathering dust in those vaults downstairs. (leans forward) If you didn't keep 'em off the market, that rock on your finger would cost less than your shoes.

dialogues.speaker: SIMMONS
dialogues.text: Fine. Write a book. Tell the BBC.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: (continuing over him) --Which is why it would be a shame if, say, another company got all the press, not the mention the profits from the largest pink ever to find its way to market~- This pulls Simmons up short.

dialogues.speaker: SIMMONS
dialogues.text: You're bluffing.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Probably. But if I'm not, you're going to be the one having to explain to Mr. De Wente how it happened. He stands and starts out.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Nice talking to you, Reg. Love the new hairline. Simmons holds up a hand, as if to say, ‘wait a second.' H flips a switch and MUSIC fills the room.

dialogues.speaker: SIMMONS
dialogues.text: What are you asking?

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Ten percent of market as a finder's fee.

dialogues.speaker: SIMMONS
dialogues.text: Five.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Seven.

dialogues.speaker: SIMMONS
dialogues.text: Agreed.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Always a pleasure doing business.  50 51 28. He turns and walks out. Simmons picks up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: SIMMONS
dialogues.text: Get me De Wente.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solomon walks out of prison to find Fawaz waiting.

dialogues.speaker: FAWAZ
dialogues.text: Solomon Vandy?

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: FAWAZ
dialogues.text: Some friends of mine thought you look like an honest man. Fawaz hands him a wad of cash and walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An abandoned school. Men, women with babies swaddled in tribal cloth. They are impatient, unruly. Solomon sees the line snaking around the block. He walks casually toward the front, acting as if he knows someone.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: Hello my brother. How's de body?

dialogues.speaker: REFUGEE
dialogues.text: Do I know you? Solomon insinuates himself beside him in line.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: Sure, sure. We met at your cousin's wedding. Don't you remember? Another refugee, farther back in line, calls out angrily.

dialogues.speaker: REFUGEE
dialogues.text: Back in line! Other refugees join in calling "end of the line," etc. Solomon ignores them, focusing on the man beside him.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: --and how is the happy couple? The angry refugee GRABS Solomon by the arm.

dialogues.speaker: REFUGEE
dialogues.text: Hey, mon, who you think you are?  52 29. Solomon turns on him with quiet menace.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: If you don't let go, I will break your arm. Then I will break your head. The wild look in Solomon's eye is truly terrifying. The m recoils in fear. The other refugees stop their grumbling.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE OFFICE 52
dialogues.text: Hundreds of NAMES, posted on reams of paper cover the wal Solomon searches the list methodically. Even as he's shov and pushed, he holds his ground. The names he seeks are n there.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Dear Jassie. Can it be that no one in our country has a home? He looks around for someone in authority. Hears an Africa SOLDIER speaking Mende.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (in Mende, subtitled) Please, I must talk to someone. My family's name is not on the list. The soldier, who is being yelled at by five other people simultaneously, replies angrily in subtitled Mende:

dialogues.speaker: MENDE SOLDIER
dialogues.text: Go to Kambe, there is another list.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: I have been to Kambe, and Mombolo, and Tibili, and--

dialogues.speaker: MENDE SOLDIER
dialogues.text: Talk to the whites. He points to a harried RED CROSS OFFICIAL who fields an onslaught of questions. Solomon pushes his way to him.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: Excuse me, sir, my name is--

dialogues.speaker: RED CROSS OFFICIAL
dialogues.text: --Check the list.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: I have checked the lists. The Brit shouts to be heard over the tumult.  53 54 55 30.

dialogues.speaker: RED CROSS OFFICIAL
dialogues.text: You have to file papers with the Office of Refugees!

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: I have filed papers!

dialogues.speaker: RED CROSS OFFICIAL
dialogues.text: Then God help you, man. Because I can't. Solomon wants to scream at him, but the Brit is right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solomon sits in the middle of the crowded street. Bereft.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: They told us freedom would make our country into a paradise. But it has turned it into a sewer instead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dia, Jassie and his sister wait for food at an R.U.F. out A rebel wearing a DOO-RAG eyes them. Dia glares as the ma offers his twelve year-old sister a Milky Way bar. Jassie pulls her daughter away but ANOTHER SOLDIER puts h arm around her waist -- pinning her arms behind her back.

dialogues.speaker: R.U.F. SOLDIER
dialogues.text: Maybe you are my new wife! Doo Rag starts to lead N'yanda away. Dia flings himself a the rebel, but OTHERS jump him and begin to beat him with their rifle butts. Jassie's screams are drowned out by th laughter of their tormentors. Dia, meanwhile, is lifted up and THROWN into the back of truck with several other TEENAGE BOYS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Archer walks to the curb. Joost is waiting beside a Merce His eyes are still black-and-blue behind sunglasses.

dialogues.speaker: JOOST
dialogues.text: He wants to see you.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: I'm going back to Sierra Leone, actually. Two Square-jawed MERCENARIES emerge from the Mercedes, th outline of handguns obvious beneath the tails of their sh  56 57

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don't suppose, ‘I'm sorry,‘ would suffice? Joost smiles thinly. The mercenaries unobtrusively hem in Archer on both sides. He expects to be pummeled at any moment. Instead they politely open the car door.

dialogues.speaker: JOOST
dialogues.text: After you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Mercedes winds it way into the South African Veldt, passing elegant stables, grape orchards and cricket pitch

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE CAR 57
dialogues.text: Archer expects to be beaten at any moment. It doesn't hap

dialogues.speaker: DRIVING DEEPER INTO THE VELDT S7A
dialogues.text: The landscape has grown barren. At a gate lined with barb wire, a sign -- “Executive Outcomes" -- is flanked by arm soldiers wearing crimson berets, who wave them on. They follow a deserted dirt road, until--

dialogues.speaker: A RUSSIAN ATTACK HELICOPTER 58
dialogues.text: materializes out of nowhere. After making a perilously cl pass, it flies away.

dialogues.speaker: BESIDE AN OLD VICTORIAN FARMHOUSE
dialogues.text: The Mercedes glides to a stop beside a spreading acacia.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL THEO COETSEE, 60,
dialogues.text: Looks like he could still lead a platoon on a fifty mile forced-march in hostile conditions. In fact, he still doe

dialogues.speaker: THE COLONEL
dialogues.text: Hello, Danny.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Sir.

dialogues.speaker: THE COLONEL
dialogues.text: You look better than Joost here.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: A misunderstanding between friends. The Colonel chuckles and pours him a marula martini.  32.

dialogues.speaker: THE COLONEL
dialogues.text: (raising his glass) Here's to us and those like us--

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: (finishing the toast) --Damn few. They sip.

dialogues.speaker: THE COLONEL
dialogues.text: I want you to come back.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Thanks but I prefer not to.

dialogues.speaker: THE COLONEL
dialogues.text: We'll be coming your way soon. Our lawyers are in conversation with the government of Sierra Leone, such as it is. Archer smiles darkly.

dialogues.speaker: THE COLONEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They want us to take back the diamond mines and I need someone who knows his way around up there. Archer just takes another sip. The Colonel studies him.

dialogues.speaker: THE COLONEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: According to our Minister Somora, you've got something in the works. Something. ..pink.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: (dismissive) The fantasy of some Mende farmer...

dialogues.speaker: THE COLONEL
dialogues.text: There is the small matter of payment on some RPG's. You haven't forgotten who arranged that shipment from our Ukranian friends...?

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: But who is it, I wonder, who tipped off the ECOMOG to the goat routine? The Colonel's tone loses some of its warmth.

dialogues.speaker: THE COLONEL
dialogues.text: Pay your debt in cash or come back to work. Your choice.  59 60 33.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: If I had a hundred grand you think I'd still be on this continent?

dialogues.speaker: THE COLONEL
dialogues.text: (laughs) Oh, Danny... You'll never leave. You're African to the bone. (dismissing him) Joost will see you back to Cape Town.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: I appreciate that. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: THE COLONEL
dialogues.text: We'll meet again soon?

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: No disrespect, sir, but I hope not.

dialogues.speaker: THE COLONEL
dialogues.text: You think selling weapons is better than using them? At least when it's you pulling the trigger, you know you're not the target. The Colonel chuckles, and gives Joost a subtle nod.

dialogues.speaker: BEHIND THE FARMHOUSE 59
dialogues.text: They approach the parked Mercedes. Archer turns to Joost.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Okay, just get it over with. The two mercenaries grab Archer's arms. Joost smiles sympathetically and then begins to beat the shit out of h INT. THE “EXECUTIVE HOTEL” - FREETOWN - DAY 60 Half of its SIGN has been blown away. A filthy red carpet leads to a colonial facade. Solomon, in a red vest that serves as a uniform, carries businessman's bags. As the businessman gets into a cab, a pack of Marlboro 100's falls out of the man's pocket.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Dear Jassie. It has been so many weeks and I still cannot find you. Solomon waits until the cab pulls away. Then he kneels an pockets the cigarettes.  61 62 63 64 65 34. INT. THE “EXECUTIVE" HOTEL - LATER 61 Solomon carries bags up a back stairs. He checks to see i anyone is watching then rifles the bags for anything of v

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At an open-air market, Solomon exchanges the cigarettes a other stolen items for hard currency.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: The city is loud and crowded and dirty. I miss the farm and cannot help wondering what has happened to the cassava crop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solomon bribes a UNICEF OFFICIAL with the currency. He walks past rows of civilian casualties, many of them children. He forces himself to smile at each face he pass

dialogues.speaker: EXT, SQUATTER'S CAMP
dialogues.text: Places like this define every city in the third world. Solomon has taken residence in the rusted hull of an old car. It is bare except for an extra shirt folded neatly.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Most of all I miss our family all together in the hut at night, the sound of the childrens’ breathing, and your warmth beside me. He lights a candle before a wooden animist statue.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Whenever I feel myself losing hope, I think of these things and I know it will be all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dia sits in a dark hut along with several TEENAGE CAPTIVE The door is flung open and GUARDS brutally drive them out form a line. Dia stands, terrified, in a driving rain.

dialogues.speaker: R.U.F. TRAINER
dialogues.text: Your mothers and fathers are dead. Your brothers and sisters are dead. You are dead too. But you will be reborn with us. We are your family now.  66 67 68 69 70 71 35.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER DAY 66
dialogues.text: Dia and others are being taught to fire an AK-47.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER DAY 67
dialogues.text: Dia carries a plastic jug of palm wine through the rebel camp. Handing it an older guerilla, he inadvertently SPIL some on the man's t-shirt. The man begins to BEAT him.

dialogues.speaker: LATER 68
dialogues.text: Dia is held down by two rebels as a cut is opened in his and an unidentified powdery drug is poured into the cut.

dialogues.speaker: LATER 69
dialogues.text: Dia is bouncing off the walls of the hut -- stoned out of his mind. Several teenage boys are similarly wasted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Archer gets out of a cab, carrying his bag. His face is swollen and sunglasses cover a black eye. A MILITARY JEEP is parked in front of his hotel. Several ECOMOG troops loiter, perhaps waiting for him, perhaps no Not taking any chances, Archer turns away. EXPLOSIONS LIKE DISTANT THUNDER rumble through the stifli night as he walks. A car is on fire. A sense of things growing out of control. A YOUNG AFRICAN WOMAN, miniskirt, big earrings beckons hi

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: You lonely tonight, Archer? (pulls down her top) I'm safe. No HIV. You use condom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Half of it is burnt. People crowd the remaining half, Grinking as heavily as ever. The African Techno-Beat thro Archer gets Med's attention at the bar, sets down his bag

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Mind looking after this for me? (M'ed nods) ...Like what you've done to the place.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER, (M'ED)
dialogues.text: Fokking R.U.F. try to hit the guv'ment building ‘cross da street. Shit, mahn, half da people heah be R.U.F. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER, (M'ED)
dialogues.text: (hands him the usual) Good for business doh. Ever'body drink much as dey can ‘fore de rebels come an drink up de rest.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Might be time to get your family out, my friend. The facade of Med's professional joviality disappears.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: And go where, mahn? Jus‘ fire up de chopper and fly away like you people? No, mahn, dis my country. We here long ‘fore you came and long after you gone. He stares at Archer, his eyes a tragic mask of defiance a despair. He turns away. Fawaz approaches. He is a nervous wreck.

dialogues.speaker: FAWAZ
dialogues.text: Oh, my God, are you all right?

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Where's the farmer?

dialogues.speaker: PAWAZ
dialogues.text: He found a job at a hotel. Spends all his time at the refugee offices. Not exactly the behavior of a man in possession of a priceless stone. Another EXPLOSION in the distant hills. Fawaz flinches.

dialogues.speaker: FAWAZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The main road to Masiaka is cut in three places. The government's gonna fall any second, and I'm following some delusional farmer. Archer sees Maddy through the crowd. She's standing apart looking somewhat dazed as she moves slowly to the music.

dialogues.speaker: FAWAZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The man was a digger. The odds of him getting away with even a small stone is zero. They slit you open alive just for sweating.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: I think Somora is looking for me.  37.

dialogues.speaker: FAWAZ
dialogues.text: (really worried now) Allah forfend...

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: (moving away) dust stay on the farmer.

dialogues.speaker: FAWAZ
dialogues.text: But-- Archer has already begun heading toward Maddy. She sees h coming and watches him walk toward her. They meet in the middle of a crowded dance floor. All around them, sweaty bodies are swaying to the African beat.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: Am I supposed to kiss you or fuck you? I can't remember.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: How about you dance with me.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: Should I ask what happened to your face? He takes her hand and leads her into the surging crowd.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I guess not. They dance as best they can in the crush.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is insane. I'm drunk in an African bar dancing with a mercenary.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: What would they say in Ohio?

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: Chicago.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: ++-You can tell a lot about someone by the way they dance.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: Then you can probably tell right away that I can't dance. They look at each other.  38.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: In Mozambique, you were part of a search-and-destroy unit targeting ANC leaders. Then in Angola, you hooked up with De Wente and started trading guns for diamonds.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Is this on the record?

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: But you blew it all getting greedy and trying to go it alone. Why? He doesn't answer. They are looking at each other. The music is pounding. Sweat is pouring off both of them but neither bothers to wipe it away. They keep

dialogues.speaker: MADDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So you're, what, a Nihilist? Opportunist? Scumbag?

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Maybe I just wasn't breast-fed in childhood.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: You think I've never met people like you?

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: I think you get off on people like me.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: Fuck you.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: That, too. dancing, their faces very close.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: What I'll...never understand... is how...you can...compartmentalize... human suffering. He stops dancing. Looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Thanks for the dance. He walks away.  39.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE THE BAR 72
dialogues.text: He lights a cigarette. She appears and stands quietly bes him. Together they watch the distant explosions.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: I didn't actually hurt your feelings? He takes a long drag. Exhales.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: How long you been in Africa?

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: Pour months. Before that Kosovo.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Okay. How many Blacks do you know back in the States -- besides the girl who cleans your house and the man who picks up your garbage?

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: What's that got to do with it?

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: I know Blacks. Grew up with ‘em, fought with ‘em. Behind the calm eyes and the gentle smile, they're burning with hate for what we've done to ‘em. They hate you, hate me, hate each other and hate themselves. And your bleeding heart isn't gonna stop ‘em butchering each other. Half the continent is starving and the rest is dying of AIDS while their leaders sell medicine to build palaces and drive Mercedes.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: That doesn't make it right.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: No it doesn't. But apart from a few do~gooders who show up for a week with their flak jackets, their laptops, and their little bottles of hand sanitizer the White world doesn't give a fuck about the Black world. Look at Sudan. Look at Rwanda. Your country loses thirty-four marines in Somalia and then does nothing as a million people die. Except put pictures of starving children on TV to flagellate their guilty conscience. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) So someone's got to do the dirty work~- you think America doesn't sell arms or hire professionals? You call them ‘contractors’. I sell guns. If I don’t, somebody else will.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: The law of the jungle. (sighs) If only I had a nickel for every piece-of-shit who uses it to justify his existence. He turns to look at her, her face radiant with sweat.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: I like your smell.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: Well, that makes me weak at the knees.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: It's all gonna blow any minute. You should get out.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: An ECOMOG relief column leaves in the morning. What about you?

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Business to finish up.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: What could possibly be worth staying and getting yourself killed over? He looks at her, offers a grim smile.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh. Right. He indicates the bare "wedding ring" finger of her left h

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Tell me you never dreamt of having a sparkly diamond of your very own. (as he walks away) +..Peace,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solomon emerges from his rusted hulk to find Archer waiti Archer looks as if he's been up all night avoiding the Minister's troops -- which in fact he has.  41.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: What did you do, bury it? Solomon instinctively looks to see if anyone is listening

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I would have buried it.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: (heart racing) What are you talking about? Archer removes his sunglasses, looks Solomon in the eye.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: What am I talking about?

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: I must go to work. Archer follows as Solomon walks through the shantytown.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: My friend Fawaz paid an awfully large bribe to get you out of jail.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: I will pay Mister Fawaz back. He has my word. And now you have my word. And we have finished speaking. Solomon runs for a crowded bus. Archer watches him disapp

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solomon is carrying bags for Western businessmen frantic get out of Freetown before it's too late. Depositing their bags in a taxi, he walks back into the l to find Archer leaning against a post, smoking a cigarett

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Why would that R.U.F. captain with the bandaged eye make up such a story. Solomon again tries to ignore him.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What are you going to do, sell it yourself? To who? For how much? You need help, friend, whether you want it or not. Another porter is eavesdropping. Solomon escapes into the alley beside the hotel, turns on Archer.  42.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: I know who you are. And what you are. Men like you have turned my country into a land of thieves and killers. I do not need your help.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: What if I could help find your family? At these words, something feral appears in Solomon's eyes

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: What do you know of my family?

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: The relief agencies are useless, the hospitals are overwhelmed. There are other ways.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: Liar!

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: I know people. White people. Solomon LUNGES -- pinning Archer against the wall. Archer could fight. He doesn't.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The...right...stone-- Solomon wants nothing more than to strangle him, but he a intuits Archer might be his only hope. He relaxes his gri

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: -~-can buy anything. Information. Safety. Even freedom. But a big stone doesn't stay secret. The minute you show it, your life is worthless. I'm guessing the only reason you're still alive is because you haven't told anyone where it is. Right? Archer's pitch -- fueled by desperation -- is mesmerizing

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The last pink to come out of Africa fetched ten million dollars. I know because I carried it out. You know what I got for it? He opens his shirt. A HUGE SCAR crosses his chest.  76 43.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I was lucky. I learned that a man will do anything for a diamond.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: You would say anything. How can I trust you--?

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Hear that? It's started. They must've snuck into the city overnight. (looks at Solomon) What's it gonna be, friend?

dialogues.speaker: A BLOCK AWAY
dialogues.text: Three cut-down trucks of Rebels SQUEAL into view and begi spraying everything with automatic weapons.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yes or no. A whole life can change with a single syllable.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: Yes. A TRUCK COMES CAREENING AROUND THE CORNER. Archer pushes Solomon as the wall behind them is stitched with bullets.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Go. GO! They begin to run.

dialogues.speaker: THEY RUN THROUGH THE CITY 76
dialogues.text: Their fates suddenly joined by the need to stay alive. And death lurks at every corner. Bands of teenagers roam the streets, FIRING AUTOMATIC WEA at anything that moves. Signs, store windows, cars. Urban Rap dopplers past as trucks with boom boxes speed by. At an intersection, an impromptu ROADBLOCK. People are pu out of cars and beaten while their cars are set on fire. Archer and Solomon double back and sprint past the Execut hotel where a gang of Rebels are entering. From inside co the sound of SCREAMING and more GUNFIRE. People are being taken -- black and white alike -- and fo into trucks. MINISTER SOMORA is led away at gunpoint.  77 78 79 44. Women are dragged by the hair into alleyways. A man is th out of a fourth-story window. In fact, it was Much worse than anything we can ever show Archer _and Solomon continue to run for their lives. Storefronts are looted. It's impossible to tell the rebel from the civilians. Adults carry televisions. Two men car a barca-lounger. Teenage boys wear womens' wigs and throw molotov cocktails made from Swedish vodka. Rebel teenager are sacking The Beach Bar -- drinking everything in sight Me'd lies dead, splayed across the bar. Archer and Solomon run through the darkening streets as rockets light up the sky. A_gun battle between retreating government soidiers and advancing rebels traps them in a crossfire. They dive into a restaurant doorway, taking refuge with o huddled, terrified, on the floor. Windows are shot out as rounds rip in and plaster rains down on their heads. After a deafening moment -- quiet. Archer watches through crack in the door as ECOMOG troops are lined up against a wall and executed.

dialogues.speaker: HOURS LATER
dialogues.text: Archer and Solomon set off again They do their best to stay in shadows, hugging the walls pock-marked buildings, as they try to sneak past the rovi patrols and trucks filled with men, and out of the city.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: How...much.... farther?

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Sooner...or...later...we'll be in the bush.

dialogues.speaker: AN HALF-HOUR LATER 78
dialogues.text: They are still running. Both men are exhausted, filthy with soot and sweat, their chests heaving. But neither even considers stopping. Arou them, the houses are becoming fewer.

dialogues.speaker: UP AHEAD
dialogues.text: And then another. Nothing beyond except a tangle of banan trees, ruined cassava groves, and the densely-covered hil  80 81 82 4s.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: There--! With renewed energy, they pick themselves up and run:

dialogues.speaker: THE SOUND OF VOICES
dialogues.text: Sends them DIVING into a ditch. Three R.U.F. soldiers are setting up a machine gun. Solom looks around wildly. There is nowhere to go. If they are still there by daybreak, they will be discovered. If they try to run, they will be shot. A look of resolve steals over Archer's face as he reaches into his boot for his knife. Without a backward glance, h slithers out of the ditch.

dialogues.speaker: THE KILLING OF THE THREE SOLDIERS 80
dialogues.text: Is a deadly ballet. One's throat is slit, the second is gutted. But his weapon FIRES -- alerting the third soldie who whirls -- just in time for his body to be stitched by rounds from the dead man's AK-47 -- which Archer now hold It has all happened in a matter of seconds. But the gunfi has alerted more soldiers from nearby.

dialogues.speaker: COME ON
dialogues.text: Archer and Solomon take off into the field -~ as TRACERS soon begin to streak past.

dialogues.speaker: AT LAST THEY BREAK INTO THE BRUSH 81
dialogues.text: Vines whipping against their faces, thorns ripping their hands and clothes -- until long after the gunfire has sto At_last they stop. Bent over double. Gasping for breath in the humid night. Alive. The two men look at one another. They could never articul it, but both intuitively know this will be the defining journey of their lives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In Cambodia, in El Salvador, in Sudan as in Sierra Leone, the image of a downtrodden, dispossessed multitude travel on foot toward an uncertain end has become the signature image of our time. It is the Age of the Refugee.  46. Archer and Solomon trudge amidst the throng. Ox-drawn car and thousands of shuffling feet churn up a sea of dust.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: Where are we going?

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: There's a relief camp in Port Loki. Journalists will have access to a SAT-phone. I'll have Fawaz meet us with the plane.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: I have agreed to nothing. Archer looks straight ahead as he walks.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: You will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a soccer stadium, ECOMOG soldiers distribute stacks of GRAIN bearing the UNICEF stencil, BOXES of MEDICAL SUPPLI Archer is outside the fence, talking to a guard. He is buffeted by hordes of refugees trying to get to the food.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: ~-I work for the Cape Town Herald. My wallet, my credentials, everything's still in Freetown. We barely got out with our lives...

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: Back away from the fence-- Archer gives up. Solomon has been watching.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: You are not a journalist.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: I'm trying to get us out of here.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: It is as I said. You will say anything. Archer sees JOURNALISTS. He waylays an Australian CAMERAM

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Hey, mate. I'm looking for somone you might know. Name's Maddy Bowen. American. If you've met her you wouldn't forget it.  84

dialogues.speaker: AUSSIE CAMERAMAN
dialogues.text: I know her.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Could you tell her Archer's here and I've got the story she wants.

dialogues.speaker: AUSSIE CAMERAMAN
dialogues.text: I'm out of here in an hour. If I see her before then, I'll tell her.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Thanks. Cheers. 84 Archer and Solomon are broiling under a relentless sun. Solomon searches every passing face. Archer dozes.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You got out.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Hello, Maddy. This is Solomon Vandy.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: How do you do? (to Archer; all business) I'm on deadline and I've been waiting four hours to use a SAT-phone. What do you want to tell me. Archer moves her out of Solomon's earshot.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: An outfit named Star Mines is buying blood diamonds.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: And...?

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: De Wente has no visible ties to Star -- but through a maze of crossholdings and offshore banks, they own it. In violation of the very trade embargo they pledged to uphold.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: You have proof of this. (he nods) And you'll go on record? He looks at her.  85 48.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: If you help me out.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: I knew it.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Before you say anything -- the man is a Mende farmer. His village was burned to the ground. He was forced to work the mines, but his family fled -- wife and three children. He's been trying to find them but he's drowning in red tape. Maddy looks again at Solomon.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: How do you even know this man?

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: I know him. Maddy looks back at Archer.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: You're using me.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: And you're using me. Isn't that how it works? (leaning in) You want to make a difference, Maddy? Start with this man. You've got access to U.N. databases, you know all the N.G.0O.'s.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: Look around, Archer. What difference does helping one man make? He looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jesus. Did I really say that? Maddy's eyes remain on his, conflicted, as we HEAR the BE OF HELICOPTER BLADES...

dialogues.speaker: EXT/INT. UNHCR HELICOPTER
dialogues.text: LOOKING DOWN on a sweep of grassland on which a sea of flapping white tents suddenly appears...thousands of them

dialogues.speaker: MADDY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: There it is.  86 87 a9.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solomon, Archer and Maddy have hitched a ride on a U.N. chopper. Solomon's never been up in one. He stares down a the sprawling tent city below.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: At the moment, the second largest refugee camp in Africa.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: My wife is here? In Guinea? Maddy reads from the computer manifest in her hand.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: Jassie Vandy, Kono District. Crossed into Guinea six weeks ago.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: Six weeks. And my children? Maddy hesitates, folds the manifest, then just nods.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: You would have found them. Sometimes it takes a year before new manifests reach the field offices. (glances at Archer) I was lucky to get access to the UNHCR database.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: I do not know how to thank you. What can Maddy say? She nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Archer, Solomon and Maddy step off the chopper to find-- SEA OF HUMANITY behind a CHAIN FENCE stretching for miles WORKERS with World Food Program armbands unload supplies REFUGEES rush the fence, pressing forward, shouting.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: This is what a million people look like. Solomon stares. These are his people. CLOSE ON ARCHER taking it all in. He's seen pretty much everything there is to see in life. But no one is unaffec  88 50.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You might catch a minute of this on CNN somewhere between weather and sports. As they approach the fence, Solomon sees that many of the refugees are AMPUTEES. Some reaching through the chain li with stumps of arms. Solomon's heart is pounding.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It says they're in Sector Two. Solomon follows as Maddy shows her BADGE to a UN GUARD, w reads her slip of paper and points out the right directio Archer stares through the fence at two KIDS, each with on leg, yet managing to kick a plastic jug back and forth. Other amputees stare sullenly. A sign reads, “NO PHOTOS F

dialogues.speaker: JOURNALISTS WITHOUT
dialogues.text: A WRINKLED OLD MAN blows his lips at Archer through the f Archer walks on. The old man shadows him. Until Archer realizes the fellow is gesturing to the cigarettes in his shirt pocket. Archer takes out a cigarette, is about to slip one through the fence -- When he sees the man has no hands. Grimly, Archer sticks the cigarette in the man's mouth. Then moves on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A FRENCH UN GUARD relays the paper to an AFRICAN WFP MONI

dialogues.speaker: FRENCH GUARD
dialogues.text: Stay at the fence. Quarantine. Solomon grips the fence, watching the WFP monitor as he disappears into the teeming mass. Archer has rejoined them. He notices Maddy's expression.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: What's wrong? Maddy shakes her head. But Archer can tell she's keeping something from him. Solomon catches sight of the WFP monitor. He has a woman with him. A woman carrying a little boy and a young girl.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: Jassie ...? (and then he's sure) Jassie! JASSIE!  51. Jassie hears her name, looks up through the hordes of peo

dialogues.speaker: JASSIE
dialogues.text: Solo! SOLO!!

dialogues.speaker: JASSIE
dialogues.text: Solomon's face morphs from disbelief to joy as Jassie run through a crush of bodies to him -- Their fingers GRASP each others through the fence. They r their hands over each others faces, unable to speak. Solomon looks at the one-year-old in her arms, an infant when last he saw him. He touches him through the fence. The girl, silent, offers a weak smile. She's seen too muc Then Solomon looks around, puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Dia? (to Jassie, in Mende) Where is Dia? The boy is nowhere in sight.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON, (CONT'D)
