dialogues.text: Where is my son? Watching this, Archer turns to Maddy.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: He has a son who goes to school, reads English.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: There were only two children listed on the manifest.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: --What? Maddy turns away, her eyes brimming. AT THE FENCE, Solomon reads Jassie's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: Where is he!? She rubs her cheek against his hand, her body trembling.

dialogues.speaker: JASSIE
dialogues.text: They...took him. Solomon looks at her, incomprehensibly. And the words com out in a flood of Mende - that breaks into a WAIL of grie  89 52. Solomon drops to the ground as if every muscle in his bod had been cut. He struggles for breath. Archer cannot watch their grief ... yet cannot turn away.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Fuck this A GUARD tries to pry Solomon's hands from the fence, but won't let go. Sensing trouble, the guard calls ANOTHER GU over. Both of them try to pull Solomon from the fence.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: Let them out. Jassie doesn't let go of her husband's hands.

dialogues.speaker: JASSIE
dialogues.text: Solo ... Solo Solomon starts shaking the fence.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: Let them out! The guards begin to beat his hands with their rifle butts But Solomon keeps shaking the fence as if to uproot the s posts.

dialogues.speaker: LET THEM OUT
dialogues.text: Archer puts himself between Solomon and the guards.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Get off him! A guard points his rifle and shouts in an unknown dialect

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Fine! Just get off him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Archer and Maddy ride in silence. Solomon stares out the chopper window. His knuckles bandaged. Devoid of emotion.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: They're afraid some of the refugees might be rebels. They won't be released until there's a cease-fire. I'm sorry. Solomon stares out at the distant fog-shrouded mountains.  90 91 53.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: What you want, Mister Archer, is beyond those hills. That is where I buried it. Archer's heart skips a beat. What was only spoken of is n real. Maddy looks at Solomon, his face knotted in grief. And th back at Archer. She is putting the pieces together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maddy marches away from the helicopter.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Maddy, wait... He grabs her arm. She wrenches free of his grip.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I didn't take his son! Don't pin that on me!

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: I pin it on all of us. Especially you.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Yah, we fucked the black man. My father did and my grandfather before him. Now the black man fucks himself. Tell me something I don't know. Tired, furious, done with sparring, she walks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solomon and Archer huddle beside a fire. Around them are hundreds of fires, each with huddled figures silhouetted. Solomon's sharpens the blade of a MACHETE with a whetston Archer pores over a MAP with a flashlight.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: You say the mine is near the Moa River. Where exactly on this map? Solomon's eyes remain on the machete blade.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: I do not need a map.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Well, I do. We follow his finger ON THE MAP as he talks.  92 54.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We're here.... The press convoy is going to Kailahun. Diamond mines are here. Where did you bury it? He looks over and sees that Solomon is CUTTING a line up arm with the machete, drawing blood.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You understand, when we get to Kailahun, we're gonna have to go overland. You better damn well be able to find it. Solomon is lost in a world of ritual.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: (almost to himself) My son is a very good student. He walks five miles to the Sisters' school every morning to study English. He is going to be a doctor one day. The pain of self-injury is an attempt to inure himself to the pain of loss. He turns away to stare into the fire. Archer has to walk away.

dialogues.speaker: NEARBY
dialogues.text: houses the paltry assortment of journalists. Archer walks past the guards with a wave of the finger. They assume -- because he is white -- that he belongs there. MADDY is hunched over a portable typewriter, typing with fingers. Archer leans over her shoulder to read.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: ",.,in the ninety degree heat, farmer Solomon Vandy drops to his knees against the chain-link fence--" Maddy whirls around. Archer finishes the sentence.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: "--rattling the wire with his powerful hands...”

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: (defensive) ..-What?

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: You think I'm exploiting his grief.  55. Archer just looks at her. She loses it.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You think I like being here? Do you have any idea what I could make back in the states writing garbage about movie stars--? (righteous fury) All anybody sees here are victims. Not people. With faces. And lives. They deserve a voice. (shaking her head) And the world deserves to know where the things they buy come from. And how much they really cost. (turns away) So get out of my face and let me work. Archer watches her work for a moment. Rubs his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: ...-Solomon thinks his son is going to be a doctor one day. (she looks up) What's the life expectancy for infants in a camp like this? What's going to happen to a twelve year-old girl? That diamond is the only chance he's got of getting his family out.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: You expect me to believe you give a rat's ass about his family.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: No. I'm just exploiting his grief. She glares at him, then looks away. There are inherent contradictions in both their intentions.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I need to get to Kailahun. The only way now is with a UN convoy. I'ma TV journalist and he's our cameraman. Maddy's shaking her head. She won't do it.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: I sewed R.U.F. diamonds into the skins of goats. I was smuggling them across the border into Liberia. Maddy is taken by surprise. She's wary but ready to liste  93 94 95 96 97 56.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The stones go to a middleman in Monrovia...

dialogues.speaker: FLASH CUT
dialogues.text: Fawaz spills a bag of rough diamonds onto the counter.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ..-who pays off a customs official who certifies the diamonds were mined in Liberia...so they can be legitimately exported.

dialogues.speaker: FLASH CUT
dialogues.text: where a CERTIFICATE OF ORIGIN bearing a Liberian seal is signed, stamped and affixed to a WOODEN BOX NAILED SHUT.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Once they reach London or the Antwerp cutting houses -- no questions asked.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE BOWELS OF THE DTC
dialogues.text: A SORTER discards the certificate of origin -~ spills the DIAMONDS onto a SORTING TABLE, mixes them with OTHER DIAM

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: They become like any other diamond.

dialogues.speaker: FLASH CUT
dialogues.text: There are many sorting tables, each with PILES OF DIAMOND Electronic surveillance cameras observe it all.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: And De Wente knows about all this?

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Supply and demand, Maddy. Control the supply and you keep demand high.

dialogues.speaker: FLASH CUT
dialogues.text: DeWente and Simmons sit before the General Assembly pious accepting the congratulations for their righteous stand.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: When African rebels flood the market with a billion dollars worth of rough, De Wente can't afford to ignore it. Technically speaking he’s not promoting the war. He's just giving them the means to do it.  98 99 100 57.

dialogues.speaker: BACK IN THE ABANDONED BUILDING
dialogues.text: Maddy's staring at Archer. He's giving her the biggest st of her career.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: You'll go on the record? Archer gives her a long look. Nods yes.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: And if I come out with this stone... Danny Archer -- such as he is -- disappears from the face of the earth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone is using strips of tape to write "TV" on the side the bus. Aboard the bus, a Spanish reporter speaks into a digital recorder. A CNN reporter chats with a French radi type. A BBC crew plays cards across the seats. Solomon stands outside the bus awkwardly holding a video- camera, a laminated PRESS ID around his neck.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: I cannot do this--

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: I am not a journalist.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Of course you're not.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: Then how can I say I am?

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Because you do, because that's how you get on the bus...Just do it! Archer and Solomon make their way down the aisle, Archer smiling to all like he belongs there, Solomon massively uncomfortable. They nod to Maddy. Solomon takes a seat beside a Spanish reporter.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: {utterly wooden) I am...the cameraman.

dialogues.speaker: EXT/INT. JOURNALIST'S BUS, (TRAVELING)
dialogues.text: The UNICEF convoy winds its way through the Kanagari hill Solomon stares out at the passing landscape.  101 102 103 104 58.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Dia. Yesterday I rode ina helicopter. Oh, my God. You would not believe how big and beautiful is this land of ours.

dialogues.speaker: A MUDDY JUNGLE TRAIL 101
dialogues.text: A platoon of child soldiers trudges along, singing a revolutionary song: "The people will benefit from the ric of their land; R.U.F. is the savior we need." A nineteen year-old leader prods Dia to sing louder.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO THE BUS 102
dialogues.text: where Solomon is talking quietly to Maddy.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I have been living in the white people's world. Computers, video- cameras and satellite phones. You would like it very much.

dialogues.speaker: AN R.U.F. ENCAMPMENT 103
dialogues.text: The child soldiers prepare for battle. Under the watchful eye of their older commanders, some field-strip weapons a paint their faces, while others sniff amphetamines. Two strong men hold Dia's arm and inject him.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: I hope you are able to keep up with your schoolwork. You must study hard if you truly hope to be a doctor.

dialogues.speaker: A FIREFIGHT IN THE JUNGLE 104
dialogues.text: A platoon of R.U.F. is ATTACKING a small hamlet. Older fighters walk behind the child soldiers, threatening to s them unless they advance. Dia fires his AK-47 indiscriminately. He kills an ox and then a man who tries to flee. Tears stream down his face.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Your mother and sisters are alive, Dia. You must keep yourself alive, too, Until I can find you. And bring you home.

dialogues.speaker: THE BUS COMES TO A SUDDEN, CREAKING STOP. 105
dialogues.text: Everyone looks out the window. Up ahead, the road is bloc by shouting VILLAGERS. ECOMOG soldiers try to keep order.

dialogues.speaker: IRISH JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: What's going on?  106 59. A RED CROSS TRUCK lies overturned on the road. Charred. A hole in its side from the RPG that hit it.

dialogues.speaker: IRISH JOURNALIST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Christ. Must have been an RPG. .The word, “RPG" has a special resonance for Archer. Came rush to grab their gear. Time to go to work.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Wait. No... The journalists push past him.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The R.U.F. is out there, just waiting for another target... It's dangerous.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: (gives him a look) Duh, She pushes past him down the aisle.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE THE BUS 106
dialogues.text: Maddy and Solomon navigate the confusion of solders and villagers. Journalists speak into recorders “... "these people, having come only to help, have now become targets A SOLDIER eyes Solomon suspiciously. Why isn't he using t camera? Archer lifts it to Solomon's eye and turns it on.

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH THE VIEWFINDER, (VIDEO IMAGE)
dialogues.text: Solomon PANS the tragic scene -- coming to rest on a MOTH begging for someone to help her wounded son. The sound of gunfire. ECOMOG troops have seen something i the tree-line and have begun exchanging fire.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Hurry it up, folks! Unless you want to end up the same way! Solomon can't move, just stares at the boy and mother.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Solomon--- let's go. Solomon puts down the camera and approaches the boy.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What are you doing? Solomon picks up the boy and begins carrying him to the b  107 108 60.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No... What are you doing!?

dialogues.speaker: AT THE BUS . 107
dialogues.text: Maddy helps the injured boy aboard. A JOURNALIST stops hi

dialogues.speaker: FRENCH JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: You can't do this -- there's no room!

dialogues.speaker: AUSSIE JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: Let ‘em on, you bloody frog! MORE JOURNALISTS join in: "ferchrissake" -- "might as wel do something!" -- "Make room" -- "Who the hell needs this

dialogues.speaker: TV CAMERAMAN
dialogues.text: Lay him across the seat. Easy-- The boy's mother chatters her thanks in Mende.

dialogues.speaker: AUSSIE JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: Where you blokes gonna sit? Good question. Archer looks around. No seats left.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Bollocks...

dialogues.speaker: COCKNEY JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: They can ride with me. Come on.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: now ride in the Land Cruiser. A loquacious COCKNEY JOURNA is driving. Ahead, the bus belches black diesel.

dialogues.speaker: COCKNEY JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: --Like the fookin' M-4. Just what this place needs, bit of environmental blight on top of the rest of it. From the passenger seat, Archer looks back and sees Maddy nodding off in the back, her head resting against the win

dialogues.speaker: COCKNEY JOURNALIST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: --Diesel fumes, toxic chemicals, pesticides, maybe a nuclear reactor or two to melt down...

dialogues.speaker: A TREMENDOUS EXPLOSION AHEAD
dialogues.text: The lead mini-bus has HIT A LAND MINE. A fireball rises into a chimney of black smoke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: R.U.F. fighters are emerging from the treeline.

dialogues.speaker: JUST AHEAD
dialogues.text: The bus is RAKED with fire. IT SKIDS TO A STOP, blocking their way. Rebels, armed with Ak-47's, close in.

dialogues.speaker: GET OFF THE ROAD
dialogues.text: But the Cockney falls against Archer, SHOT in the head. T car KEEPS MOVING as Archer tries to reach past the dead m and grab the wheel. Before he can gain control: THE LAND CRUISER CAREENS off the shoulder of the road, SMASHING into a tree. GUNFIRE shatters their windows as Solomon THROWS HIMSELF top of Maddy, pushing her down to the floor of the vehicl ARCHER manages to push the dead journalist out the door a throw the Land Cruiser into reverse. R.U.F. FIGHTERS -- who have been running toward the car - are forced to scatter or else be run over. As Archer rams the shifter into first, a REBEL runs up to the car from behind, his weapon held above his head, prep to shoot down into the back seat. Just as he FIRES, the c lurches forward and his bullets stitch the cargo hatch.

dialogues.speaker: THE LAND CRUISER
dialogues.text: Swerves away, taking off the front bumper of the lead tru A rebel raises an RPG to his shoulder, takes aim. Fires. ARCHER swerves at the last moment. The RPG passes by, its exhaust trail the only evidence of the near-miss. They crashe headlong into the brush. It's a bone-jarring ride: jagged branches loom and penetrate the windows, the chassis groans as tires pound over roots and hidden bould

dialogues.speaker: BACK ON THE ROAD
dialogues.text: Journalists are rousted at gunpoint toward an uncertain f

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Land Cruiser emerges from the bush. It's a wreck. The wheels grind against the wells, two tires are flat, smash windshield, bullet holes along its length. Archer stops and has to force the door open to get out. H peers under the bonnet. Bullet holes. It's hopeless.  110 lll 62.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Grab your things. They have no choice but to set off on foot.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: As they trudge along under a bright canopy of stars. One might even think of diamonds. Archer uses dead reckoning.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: The Southern Cross. Long as we head North, we'll hit the main road. They walk in silence for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: What do you think happened to the people on the bus.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: You really want to think about it? Up ahead, Solomon stares up at a particularly bright star

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: Kya kwayera taarig.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: We call it Venus.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: We say the moon's wife. (pointing) She follows him through the sky. Two days before the new moon, she comes out alone, looking for him. The moon and his wife are never separated for very long. He is thinking of Jassie. Maddy is moved.

dialogues.speaker: AT FIRST LIGHT
dialogues.text: Looms out of the jungle as they walk a narrow track. Pornographic GRAFFITI has been spray-painted on the churc and "West Side Niggaz." HEADLESS BODIES hang from the tre

dialogues.speaker: SUDDENLY
dialogues.text: Come a scary-looking band of semi-primitive natives adorn with colorful amulets, shells and talismans. They carry a miscellany of handguns, machetes and spears.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: Be very still. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do not look them in the eye. (to Archer) They are Kamajor. The HEADSMAN gestures angrily at Archer. Solomon lowers h eyes and responds deferentially. Archer whispers to Maddy

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Local militia. Protecting their homes. The Headsman gestures with his machete. Several of his me prod Archer forward with an old double-barreled shotgun.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: Archer looks around for any means of escape. There is non

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They emerge from the bush to discover a cluster of buildi untouched by the ravages of war. Flowering gardens and ne raked paths. After all they have seen, it seems dreamlike

dialogues.speaker: A GROUP OF CHILDREN
dialogues.text: Emerge from the building and race toward them.

dialogues.speaker: MENDE CHILDREN
dialogues.text: Where are you from? Have you come from America? Do you have CD's? A GENTLE VOICE calls out.

dialogues.speaker: GENTLE VOICE
dialogues.text: Don't be bothering the people now. Let them come in. The children instantly obey. BENJAMIN KAPANAY appears in doorway. He is a tall, sixty-five year-old distinguished- looking Mende with a trim white beard.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: (in Mende; subtitles) Thank you, Ubani. You can leave them here. I take responsibility.

dialogues.speaker: KAMAJOR HEADMAN
dialogues.text: {in Mende; subtitles) Good. Now they are your problem. The Kamajors back away, vanishing into the forest.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: If you're looking for money, weapons or fuel, I don't have any.  64.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: How about food?

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: If you ask politely. My name is Benjamin Kapanay.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Danny Archer. And this is--

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: --Maddy Bowen. How do you do?

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: Very well, thank you. Chicago?

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: How--

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: --I recognize the accent. (to Solomon; in Mende) Welcome, Brother.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: (in Mende; subtitles) I am Solomon Vandy, from Bo.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: (in Mende; subtitles) What should I make of your companions? Solomon doesn't know how to answer. He lies badly.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: (in Mende; subtitles) They are... journalists.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: (in Mende; subtitles) Ah. And I suppose you are, too. Solomon looks away, ashamed. Benjamin turns to Maddy.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Might I interest you in a glass of lemonade?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Under a covered porch, they eat lunch -- served by Benjam young Mende wife and his three children.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: -- I don't understand why anyone would willingly live in that cold. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The wind off the lake. I cried every night my first winter.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: How did you end up at Northwestern?

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: Because of President Kennedy, who else?

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: By way of James McGrath, a young Peace Corps volunteer from Winnetka -- who found a semi-literate Mende boy and was foolish enough to believe he could benefit from higher education.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: How long were you in the States?

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: Which time? I ended up getting my Masters at Stanford -- better climate.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: But you came back?

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: To show my people the way. Hah. They are served a platter of vegetables by a well-mannere ten year-old boy. Benjamin's son, UCHENNA.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thank you, Uchenna.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: You built this school?

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: Starting in 1967. Children from all over the district find their way here. Over five hundred graduates since we began.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: That's remarkable. Would you mind if I turned on my tape recorder.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: I'll make you a deal, Miss Bowen -- I give you an interview and you teach at my school for a month.  116 117 66.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: (laughs) I'd like that.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: But you won't do it.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: An honest journalist, how refeshing. The truth is, I have done well to keep a low profile. This is a very dangerous part of the country with the diamond mines so close by. Solomon, meanwhile, hasn't been able to take his eyes off Benjamin's young son. The boy smiles back at him.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: My son wants to be a doctor.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: Very good. Where is he now? A silence.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: We don't know.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: I understand...

dialogues.speaker: A SERIES OF IMAGES 116
dialogues.text: Benjamin gives them a tour: a group of eight year-olds cr around a single computer; a ten year-old girl is being ta to use an artificial limb; twelve year-old boys play cric

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: Many of these children were taken by the R.U.F. We have taken them back. (looks at Solomon) Some of them have been made to do horrible things. We are trying to bring them back to life. Solomon turns away to hide the surge of emotion.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: They sit drinking wine. The African sunset is inimitable.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: -- it was all very clear in 1964. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Political freedom plus economic development equals happiness. But sometimes revolution leads to chaos and economic opportunity doesn't necessarily bring out the best in people. Certain personality types realized freedom could be another name for greed. (raises his glass) And here we are.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: But look what you've accomplished.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: And look what good it has done my country...

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: "There is no easy walk to freedom." We can only do the best we can.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: Mandela. His best is a bit better than mine... He takes a long look at his children.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Had many attacks in the area?

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: I've known most of the young people in this district since they were born. The local commander is still afraid I'll come after him with my ruler.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: You think because your intentions are good they'll spare you? Benjamin takes the question in stride.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: My heart always told me that people are inherently good. My experience suggests otherwise. Which to believe? Benjamin turns his penetrating gaze on Archer.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What about you, Mr. Archer? In your long career as a...journalist... Would you say people are mostly good?  68. Archer stares back. The SOUND of A CHILDREN'S CHOIR...

dialogues.speaker: IN THE CENTER OF THE VILLAGE
dialogues.text: The children are singing "High We Exult Thee, Realm of th Free," the national anthem of Sierra Leone. Solomon and Maddy sit with Benjamin and his family. Maddy sees Archer get up and walk away.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE EDGE OF THE COMPOUND 119
dialogues.text: Archer stands alone. He takes a long pull from a plastic jug. Maddy steps out from the shadows.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Palm wine. Sap comes right out of the tree. He offers to her and she takes a swig. Makes a face.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You get used to it. He takes another long drink. He's pretty drunk.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Drank this as a boy.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: Rhodesia. (off his look) I take notes. Indeed, her little spiral notebook is already in hand. He looks at her ~- considering -- then, what the hell...

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: I got sent to South Africa when the muntz overran the farm in '76.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: --After you lost your parents.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: (dark laugh) That's a polite way of putting it. Mum was raped. Dad was decapitated and hung from a hook in the barn.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: You were, what, ten years old?

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Nine. Boo-hoo.  69.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: Then at eighteen you joined the army... Archer peers at her.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Want to hear about the first time I banged a journalist? She just looks at him. He takes another long drink. Relen

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yah, yah. First they had us doing dirty little jobs in the townships.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: With the Security services.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: You think you know about the Security services? (another dark laugh) You don't know shite. That was a picnic compared to what we did on the Moz border. Sometimes I think, ‘God will forgive us for what we did.' Then I look around and I wonder...what would God want with a Place like this? He takes another drink but the jug is empty. He tosses it

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: By '94 I'ma ten years vet. Then poof. No more apartheid, no more army. Thanks very much, see ya later. Truth and reconciliation. Kumbaya. He raises his middle finger in a universal gesture.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They told us we were fighting Communism. Protecting our ‘way of life.’ (a rueful laugh) It's about who gets what. Oil. Coltan. Diamonds. So one day I decided, fuck it, now I want mine.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: Are you going to steal his diamond?

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: We have no chance in hell of getting the diamond.  70.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: Doesn't answer the question.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: That diamond -- whether I steal it or just take the commission -- is my ticket out of here.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: To go where? Archer hasn't gotten that far in his thinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjamin drives them down roads that are little more than animal tracks. Bush pigs scamper. Chimpanzees chatter abo Solomon looks up into the canopy of forest as the sun dar in and out of view.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Dear Dia. I have found a place for your studies once you return home. Benjamin shows Maddy the hippos splashing in the river.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: Do not be fooled by the movie where they wear pink skirts and dance on their toes. They are extremely dangerous, easily angered, and very fast. Benjamin's love of all that he sees is infectious. As he plays tour guide, they forget for a moment their dire circumstances and surrender to the joys of the natural wo

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: There is a man I want you to meet. He is a teacher. You will like him. Benjamin turns a wry eye to Archer.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: What story will you be covering when I drop you in Kailahun, Mr. Archer?

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Thank you for your help, Mr. Kapanay. I won't forget it.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: I hope the story will end the way you want it to.  71.

dialogues.speaker: UP AHEAD
dialogues.text: guarded by TWO TWELVE YEAR-OLD CHILD SOLDIERS.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Keep going.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: What--?

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Drive right at them. They'll panic. Instead Benjamin slows the car.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: Do you know where the word, ‘infantry' comes from? It means child soldier. They are just children.

dialogues.speaker: THE TWO R.U.F. SOLDIERS
dialogues.text: are indeed children. One wears a Michael Jordan jersey, t other has skateboard stickers on his Ingram submachine gu But their eyes are glazed and deadened.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hello, little brothers. What are your names?

dialogues.speaker: CHILD SOLDIER
dialogues.text: I am Dead Body. Who dis mothafuckah?

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: We are teachers on our way to Kailahun.

dialogues.speaker: CHILD SOLDIER
dialogues.text: Only R.U.F on da road!

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: I understand but we have to--

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: Now listen here! I am-~ The boy FIRES HIS WEAPON without warning. Benjamin is hit in the chest.

dialogues.speaker: JESUS FUCKING CHRIST
dialogues.text: 122 123 125 72. He leans over and STOMPS ON THE GAS PEDAL. The car LURCHE FORWARD, knocking aside the other boy. Archer has to practically straddle the wounded man to speed away.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE CAR, (TRAVELING)
dialogues.text: Benjamin tries to speak. Blood bubbles from his lips.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Do NOT try to talk. If you're not dead, it's only because you're hit in the lung not the heart. Solomon is leaning over the seat, opening Benjamin's shir

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Solomon) Don't worry about the entry wound. Lean him forward, there's going to be a big hole in his back. Press your hand against it. Keep it there. (to Maddy) If there's any wine left in that jug, pour it all over everything. (to Benjamin) How far to Kailahun?

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: (weakly) You...said...not to talk.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: A fucking comedian. He pushes the old car's accelerator to its limit.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE CAR, (TRAVELING)
dialogues.text: Benjamin is slumped, unconscious, against the passenger d

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: How's his pulse?

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: It's a pulse.

dialogues.speaker: ROUNDING A BEND 124
dialogues.text: They are suddenly confronted by two ARMORED CARS and a pl of white mercenaries carrying Uzi's. The soldiers all wea maroon berets with the initials E.O.

dialogues.speaker: MOMENTS LATER
dialogues.text: Archer and Solomon help place him on a litter. He is conscious again.  73.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: You'll be all right.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: (looks him in the eye) Will you? He is hurried away as--

dialogues.speaker: AN ATTACK HELICOPTER TAKES OFF NEARBY
dialogues.text: Raising a cloud of dust. Joost appears out of the confusi Joost Archer...what the fuck--

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Good to see you, too, Joost. Maddy is furiously scribbling notes of all she sees. Joos? We're evacuating all non-military personnel. Relief workers, journalists. (to Archer) Shite-bags.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: How far's the front line?

dialogues.speaker: JOOST
dialogues.text: There is no front line. Little buggers are everywhere. (starts off) Colonel's this way.

dialogues.speaker: THE COLONEL'S HQ 126
dialogues.text: A large tent. The Colonel pores over a map while talking a SAT-phone. Archer and Joost enter.

dialogues.speaker: THE COLONEL
dialogues.text: (on the phone) ~-but if we block their escape by cutting the bridge-- (sees Archer) Wait One... (covers the mouthpiece) Archer. Don't want to say I told you so--

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: But you will.

dialogues.speaker: THE COLONEL
dialogues.text: The Sierra Leone government has hired us to recapture the diamond mines.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: In return for a mining concession or two, no doubt.

dialogues.speaker: THE COLONEL
dialogues.text: {a modest nod) I've got a C-130 touching down at 1400. Everybody not prepared to get dirty is on it. (checks his watch) You've got thirty minutes to make up your mind. You're either with us or out of here. He turns back to his conversation. Archer is dismissed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maddy is waiting as Archer walks back.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: How is he?

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: They say he'll live.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: You're on a plane for Ghana in half an hour. (looks at her) Do me one last favor. Maddy just looks at him. Archer indicates a young MERCENA standing guard in front of a large supply tent.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Go tell that guard you want to put his face on the cover of Soldier of Fortune magazine.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: You're going in. (Archer nods) You and Solomon. Archer nods again. She shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now? (another nod) You're an idiot.  128 129 75.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Help me or not? Maddy shakes her head sadly. She turns away, pushing the hair out of her face as she approaches the YOUNG MERCENAR

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: Hi, there. Maddy Bowen, Vanity Fair. You mind if I ask you a few questions?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MERCENARY
dialogues.text: Depends what they are-~-

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: Oh, So you're familiar with our devious ways, are you? She flashes a devastating smile. And while his back is turned, we SEE Archer edge past toward the back of the te

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE SUPPLY TENT 128
dialogues.text: Archer forages for whatever he can lay his hands on. Into his pack he stuffs K-rations, a GPS, first-aid kit. He desperately looks for one more thing. And there it is. A SaAT-phone. He stuffs it in. Outside, the SOUND of a pl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A giant C-130 Hercules touches down.

dialogues.speaker: THE SWARM OF JOURNALISTS
dialogues.text: Aid workers, and refugees surge onto the tarmac. Carrying her bag, Maddy moves against the tide, looking around. Solomon appears beside her, subtly taking her arn.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: This way. ARCHER is waiting behind a tent, the pack already on his shoulders. She turns to Solomon.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: Good luck to you, Solomon Bo. Solomon takes her hand in both of his.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: Thank you for all you've done.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: I hope you find what you're looking for. She turns to Archer. They look at each other.  76.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Yeah. Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: --dJust keeping my end of the deal. A moment of silence. She can be as tough as he can.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Listen--

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: No, you listen-- And they just stare at each other.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: In another life, maybe.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: Sure... Okay...

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Find yourself a good man, Maddy. You deserve to be happy. She considers him -- wishing she were less affected by hi

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: I have three sisters. All married to “good men." Long as their prescriptions are filled they're happy. No thanks. I prefer my life. (hands him her card) Office phone, home phone, cell phone. I'm used to being pursued, but what the hell. He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It's a world phone, by the way.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: You should get on the plane.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: So should you. He smiles and turns away.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are you going to call me?

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Soon as I'm near a phone...  130 131 132 133 77.

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: Yeah, right. She turns toward the plane. They head the opposite way.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE BUSH 130
dialogues.text: Archer and Solomon begin to jog.

dialogues.speaker: BACK AT THE AIRSTRIP 131
dialogues.text: Maddy is about to board the plane when Joost waylays her.

dialogues.speaker: JOOST
dialogues.text: Where is he?

dialogues.speaker: MADDY
dialogues.text: Where is who? She continues up the steps to the plane. Joost looks arou No sign of Archer. The wheels begin to turn in his head.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER AND SOLOMON TREK 132
dialogues.text: into the bush. They move quickly, putting distance betwee themselves and the E.O.camp. As they run, THE CAMERA rise up, higher and higher, until their tiny figures have disappeared and the FRAME IS FILLED WITH NOTHING BUT GREE We sense of the immensity of the challenge that lies ahea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Archer and Solomon have stopped to catch their breath. Ar digs out the SAT-phone, fires it up and punches in a numb

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: (on the phone) ..-Fawaz?  ...1 know. No time now.... That's right....Two days to get in, one to get out. I'11 call when we're headed for the strip. Right... ‘Bye. He looks up to see if Solomon has been listening. But Sol is staring off into the jungle.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON, (V.0,)
dialogues.text: Dear Dia. I am coming. With every step I am closer. I can feel you are nearby. I am coming soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A column of R.U.F. guerrillas walk a jungle trail. We can SEE by the gouges of earth that they are in diamond count Dia, looking much older, carries an AK-47.  135 136 137 138 78.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO ARCHER AND SOLOMON 135
dialogues.text: as he stuffs the SAT-phone into his back. He sets off wit a word, knowing Solomon will follow.

dialogues.speaker: THEY TRAVEL BY NIGHT 136
dialogues.text: On narrow dirt roads, lit only by the moon.

dialogues.speaker: HEADLIGHTS APPROACH 137
dialogues.text: Archer and Solomon take cover as TRUCKS pass filled with R.U.F. teenagers, laughing, smoking ganja, music blasting Solomon studies each passing face. Almost involuntarily h rises to his feet -~ trying to get a better look. Suddenl he thinks he sees a familiar face -~ could it be Dia? He moves closer -- but the truck is moving away.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: Dia!! Heads turn in the passing truck. It's not Dia. Suddenly Solomon is grabbed from behind and thrown to the ground. Archer looms over him.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: What the fuck are you doing!!

dialogues.speaker: GET OFF ME
dialogues.text: Meanwhile, on the road, the trucks have slowed. Suddenly-

dialogues.speaker: THE BRUSH EXPLODES WITH GUNFIRE
dialogues.text: Red and Green TRACERS shred the dense foliage around them Bullets WHIZ by their heads, RICOCHET off ancient trees. They scramble to their feet and race blindly back into th bush. Behind them, the SOUND of their pursuers. Soon the brush grows more dense. In the pitch darkness th are literally fighting their way forward, flailing with b arms to rip holes through the thick foliage. Their hands and faces are soon cut and bleeding.

dialogues.speaker: THEY RUN 138
dialogues.text: Until they can run no further. Archer stumbles and falls. Solomon crumples to the ground beside him. As they lie th winded, they HEAR VOICES. They can see the GLOW OF CIGARETTES through the foliage o a few yards away as R.U.F. soldiers approach.  139

dialogues.speaker: ON SOLOMON AND ARCHER
dialogues.text: as the soldiers’ boots pass within inches of their hiding place. They bury their faces deeper in the mud.

dialogues.speaker: DAYBREAK 139
dialogues.text: finds them still hiding. Cautiously, they emerge -- stiff wet, and miserable from a night spent on the jungle floor

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: (furious) Next time you pull something like that I will shoot you myself.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: (equally furious) Shoot me now. It is what you are planning anyway.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: You think I do not know the kind of Man you are? You buy diamonds from the same people who took my son.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: --Maddy told you.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: Is this true? Archer looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Yes. It is true.

dialogues.speaker: . SOLOMON
dialogues.text: And all you have said... How the diamond will free my family. This, too, is a lie. Is it not?

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: I don't know. Maybe. (looks at him) But I'm not the only one who tells lies, am I?

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: I do not lie.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: No? You don't give a fuck about finding the diamond. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're out here looking for your son. And you'd cut my heart out in a second if it means a chance to get him back. Solomon is shocked into silence. Archer is right.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: Yes. It is true. The two men stare at each other.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Long as we understand each other. He sets off into the brush, limping heavily.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: You are hurt.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: (without looking back) I'm fine. Solomon reaches to take the heavy pack from Archer's shou Archer grabs his hand. They lock eyes for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: You think I'm going to steal it? Archer turns and walks away. Solomon looks down to see BR DROPS OF BLOOD from Archer's boot staining the ground.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: forces them to take cover. Two E.O. gunships streak past. Are the choppers looking for them, or is it a coincidence

dialogues.speaker: LATER THAT DAY
dialogues.text: as they trudge onward. Archer's limp is more pronounced. He tips back his canteen and finds it empty. Solomon noti He passes his canteen to Archer, who hesitates for a mome then laughs and puts his mouth to a black man's canteen.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: In the distance, we see the receding peaks. Archer begins conversation, as much out of boredom as anything else.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: So you're a farmer... Solomon looks at him warily. Nods.  143 144 gl.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What do you grow?

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: teeeee Casava.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: I grew up on a farn. (remembering...) Hated every minute of it. End of conversation. They walk on in silence.

dialogues.speaker: STILL LATER
dialogues.text: Begin to appear as Archer and Solomon climb through a hil landscape. Solomon stares at the diamond mines.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: It is like they are eating the earth. He walks on. Archer labors to keep up with Solomon's pace

dialogues.speaker: ABANDONED HOUSES 144
dialogues.text: caved-in and listing, line a street where deep pits have been dug beneath their foundations. Impoverished SQUATTER follow them with listless, hungry eyes as they pass. Archer is jittery to be observed. But in Africa, people a everywhere. Blood squishes in his boot as he walks.

dialogues.speaker: BY SUNSET 145
dialogues.text: They have been walking for twelve hours. Archer has to si

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: How much farther--?

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: One day more. He kneels before Archer.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let me see your leg.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: It's fine. Solomon touches it and Archer GRUNTS in pain.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It's infected. From lying there all fucking night. Solomon lifts Archer's pant leg. Examines it.  146 147 82.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: Give me your knife.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: In the other boot. Solomon takes the K-Bar. Archer grits his teeth. We canno see what Solomon does -- but from the expression on Arche face, we can only imagine. Solomon stands. Archer tries to but the pain is overwhelm

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: I will be back. Archer pulls his Sig-Sauer 9mm from his belt.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: No-- Solomon starts walking away. COCKS the weapon.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You think I won't shoot you.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: Shoot me, then. And try to find the diamond yourself. (keeps walking) IT will be back.

dialogues.speaker: LATER THAT NIGHT
dialogues.text: has been taken over by CHILD SOLDIERS. They sit, throwing bullets into a barrel fire and LAUGHING as they explode. Solomon creeps to the edge of a hut -- peering at the fac No Dia. Six more teenagers are loading the spoils of the village onto a truck. One of them could be Dia. He isn't.

dialogues.speaker: HOURS LATER
dialogues.text: Archer awakens to see Solomon walking toward him out of t bush. He carries a poultice made of leaves and mud. He kneels and begins to apply it to Archer's wound.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: I thought about not coming back. (looks at him) I talked to my son about it. Archer looks at him. What the hell is he talking about?  148 149 83.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I talk to him all the time. (works on the leg) He says I must forgive what you have done in the past. And trust that you will help get my family back. Archer doesn't know how to respond to this simple absolut

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: You're fucking crazy. Solomon finishes wrapping the poultice.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: I will go and find us water. He stands again and walks away. Archer can't bear feeling powerless. Fighting the pain, h stands and tries to walk. It's excruciating. Still he continues hobbling -- until finally he sits on the ground

dialogues.speaker: CAPE TOWN AIRPORT TERMINAL
dialogues.text: Maddy de-planes with a contingent of journalists. Like everyone else who gets off a plane these days, she turns her cell phone to check for messages. There are none. Archer hasn't called.

dialogues.speaker: DAWN IN THE JUNGLE 149
dialogues.text: is soft and full of promise. Low clouds hang just above t treetops as first light touches the moist greenery. Archer's face is at peace as he wakes. Solomon sleeps nea Archer reaches to scratch his nose and realizes he is cov with BLACK ANTS. Scrambling to his knees, he frantically brushes them off. They are in his ears, inside his shirt. Solomon awakens and begins to laugh at Archer's frenzy.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Tt HATE FUCKING ANTS!

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: I think you are feeling better. And then Solomon realizes that he, too, is infested. He reaches into his pants and begins to hop around. Now it's Archer's turn to laugh. Soon they are both sitting on the ground, LAUGHING for no reason -- except, of Course, as a release from all that h befallen them.  84.

dialogues.speaker: THE ENDLESS HILLS 150
dialogues.text: glow pink in the dawn as they walk. A herd of antelope bu from the brush and bound majestically away.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: ++.¥ou are how old?

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Me? Thirty. One.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: And you have no wife?

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: No children?

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: No. Solomon shakes his head. After a moment, Archer can‘t res

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: --What?

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: Truly, I do not understand white people.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: That makes two of us.

dialogues.speaker: AS THEY CREST A HILL
dialogues.text: Solomon suddenly stops. He looks around. Then he falls to his knees. Archer climbs to where he is and looks around-

dialogues.speaker: A MASS GRAVE
dialogues.text: has been fashioned from an abandoned diamond pit. BODIES piled high -- men, women, children. None of them soldiers

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Animals.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: No animal would ever do such a thing. It makes no sense. Solomon forces himself to walk among the corpses, praying that his son is not among them. Tears stream down his che  85.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My people value life. The Mende find it hard even to take the life of a chicken. God gives life; only he may take it back. {a strangled cry) How can they do this? Archer has no answer. Just looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (numbly) Why is there so much evil here? What is wrong with us?

dialogues.speaker: HOURS LATER 151
dialogues.text: Archer uses a tree branch as a cane.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: (feeling his forehead) I've stopped sweating. We've got to find water.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: Then we must move faster. Archer nods and pushes himself past the pain in his leg. o

dialogues.speaker: HOURS LATER
dialogues.text: Archer stumbles. Solomon offers a hand to lift him to his feet. Archer ignores it. Ahead is a CLEARING, and in it:

dialogues.speaker: A BULL ELEPHANT
dialogues.text: stands tall and menacing. Beside him, on the ground, is h Mate -- grievously wounded and BELLOWING piteously. For a moment, Archer and Solomon are too stunned to speak

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Back away. And watch where you step. Solomon freezes.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: Is it--

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: A minefield. Yes. They stare at the MAGNIFICENT CREATURE who refuses to lea his fallen mate. Slowly they retrace their steps. —~ No sooner have they turned their backs than AN EXPLOSI shakes the ground and A FLOCK OF BIRDS rises over the fie  153 154 86. They know what it means. Grimly, they keep moving.

dialogues.speaker: THE JUNGLE AT NIGHT 153
dialogues.text: is a freaky place at the best of times with strange shape shadows, and noises everywhere. In their state, it feels like a bad acid trip. Solomon hears the WHISPERED VOICE o his son. He carries on an imagined conversation.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: ....Why? The cows will do fine in the upper pasture...

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Hey...

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: (in a kind of trance) -- Yes. And next year we will plant coffee--

dialogues.speaker: HEY
dialogues.text: (Solomon is startled) You're hallucinating.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: No. I am not.

dialogues.speaker: HOURS LATER
dialogues.text: Archer is half-asleep as they trudge through deep jungle. He stops suddenly. A SNAKE hangs menacingly from a tree.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Do you see that?

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: The. ..snake.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Good. Archer now sees that it is only a tree branch.

dialogues.speaker: THEY WALK ON FOR A MOMENT
dialogues.text: This time it is Solomon who stops short.  155 156 87.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: Wait... (listening) Can you hear it? Archer listens hard. A weird croaking sound. Frogs?

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Progs!!

dialogues.speaker: YES
dialogues.text: Frogs mean water. They stumble forward to discover--

dialogues.speaker: A SMALL STREAM BED
dialogues.text: They fling themselves onto their bellies and begin to dri

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: What if...this water...is bad?

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: You can wait for beer. Good point. Archer drinks his fill.

dialogues.speaker: THE NEXT MORNING 155
dialogues.text: Finds them sitting by the stream. Archer studies his map.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: This must be the Meli. It runs from the North. The Moa runs from the East. Where the rivers meet is where the mine is, right? Solomon says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Right? Solomon just glares at him.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You get that diamond, you can hire a team of people to find him. You can buy the whole damn government! (leaning in) What are you gonna do, spend the rest of your life searching the bush? Solomon looks at him. Yes. If necessary.

dialogues.speaker: HOURS LATER
dialogues.text: now grown into a broad river.  157 88.

dialogues.speaker: HOURS LATER
dialogues.text: Archer is struggling. Once again, Solomon offers a hand t help him over a boulder. This time, Archer grudgingly acc the hand. The moment is underplayed but deeply significan Cresting a hill, Solomon looks down on the confluence of two rivers. A familiar gorge.

dialogues.speaker: THE DIAMOND MINING CAMP
dialogues.text: is spread out below. HOLES and PITS pock the landscape. Archer joins him at the overlook.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: That's it, isn't it? Solomon's face is clouded with memory. It's a place from nightmares. A place he hoped never to see again.

dialogues.speaker: A LARGE CONTINGENT OF R.U.F. TROOPS
dialogues.text: is encamped near the mines. Archer can see dozens of tiny fires with troops huddled beside them.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Christ. He kneels -- trying to figure out their next move.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay... He digs into his pack for the SAT-phone.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The E.O. would want to know about a force this size. If I call Joost, he'll send in an air strike... (the plan unfolds) We use it as a diversion. Below them, TEENAGE REBELS play soccer in a ragged field. Is Dia among them? It is too far away to know.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: No air strike.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: How do we get in there without some kind of diversion?

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: No...air...strike.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: He isn't down there.  158 89.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: How do you know?

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: (coldly) I'm calling it in. (turns on SAT-phone) They'1l come in at first light. Low. Over that ridge. That's how Much time you've got. Solomon turns and starts down the hill.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hold up there, boy--! Solomon reacts to Archer's instinctive use of "boy."

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm not letting you get yourself killed until I have that fucking stone. We wait for dark. A LIST OF CALL NUMBERS is taped to the inside of the SAT- phone's case. Archer punches in a number.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (on the SAT-phone) Get me Joost..... Archer....He'll know-- Ask if he's interested in the location of a major R.U.F. camp......

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: is just as we remember it. Muddy and exhausted SLAVE WORK try to keep out of A DRIVING RAIN, squatting under corrug tin roofs while eating their tiny portion of rice gruel. Rebel soldiers -- adults and teenagers alike -- eat Red C rations while trying to keep warm and dry.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER AND SOLOMON
dialogues.text: have crawled forward to the edge of the camp.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: I can't walk in there. you stay in my line of sight and I'll cover you. If he's not there, we move around the perimeter. The air strike happens at 0600. (racks the slide of his Sig-Sauer) You do exactly as I say. And don't mistake me for your friend. You fuck with me and I'll surely kill you.  159 161 162 90.

dialogues.speaker: A SENTRY
dialogues.text: huddles miserably in the rain. Archer SPRINGS out of the shadows and choke-holds him -- then drags him back into the bushes where Solomon is hidi Archer takes his weapon - an H&K assault rifle. Solomon stands up and walks into the camp as inconspicuou as possible. Archer watches under cover of the brush as:

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON 159
dialogues.text: insinuates himself among the miserable workers, moving fr hut to hut -- trying to see if Dia is among them. He isn't. Solomon moves deeper into the village.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: curses as Solomon walks out of his line of sight.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE CAMP 160
dialogues.text: Solomon is about to give up hope, when-- HE SEES DIA. Solomon blinks back his disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dia's with TWO OLDER REBELS, who are watching him take a from a big spliff, laughing as he chokes on the smoke. Solomon tries to will Dia to turn in his direction.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER 161
dialogues.text: Scuttles through the bush -- trying to get a line of sigh

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: appear nearby -- carrying food for the sentry Archer has killed. Unable to find him, they begin to CALL out for hi

dialogues.speaker: IN THE CAMP 163
dialogues.text: Dia and the other soldiers separate. Solomon moves out fr the shadows.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: (whispering) Dia-- Dia turns -- uncomprehending. Solomon takes his arm.  165 166 91.

dialogues.speaker: DIA
dialogues.text: (suddenly fearful)

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: Dia, it's me! Three months of horror, of depravation, of trauma, of unspeakable acts have taken root in the soul of this youn boy. His face contorts in struggle. Then--

dialogues.speaker: GET AWAY FROM ME
dialogues.text: (screaming)

dialogues.speaker: FARMER
dialogues.text: He tries to break free of Solomon's grasp. A few other soldiers HEAR him cry out. They turn to look.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER 164
dialogues.text: hears it as well. He steps from his hiding place -- tryin to see what is happening.

dialogues.speaker: AN R.U.F. SOLDIER 165
dialogues.text: sees Solomon holding Dia by the arm. He HITS HIM IN THE BACK with his rifle butt. Solomon crumples to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER 166
dialogues.text: aims the assault rifle, but the GUARDS have picked up Sol and -- at sixty yards, at night, in the driving rain -- there's no way Archer can get off a clean shot. Then-- The SOUND of a SLIDE being racked. The barrel of an AK-47 is placed against Archer's head.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, THE REBEL CAMP
dialogues.text: Solomon's arms have been TIED behind his back -- the rope looped over a tree branch and re-tied. He looks up to see DIA, standing with several guards. His face is hard and withdrawn. He turns away from Solomon's gaze. A SHOVEL is thrown at Solomon's feet.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: I knew you would come back. Solomon looks up into the disfigured face of CAPTAIN POIS A brutal scar only adds to the malice in his eyes. Poison motions to the dozens of HOLES that pock the lands giant scars of diamond fields that have been mined out.  92.

dialogues.speaker: POISON
dialogues.text: See how I have dug. I have found nothing. (to Solomon) You will dig again for me. You will dig up what you have come back for.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: POISON
dialogues.text: No? Do you think the white man will rescue you? He turns Solomon's head violently to the left, where:

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Has been made to kneel, arms tied behind his back, head t the ground, with a gun held to the back of his skull.

dialogues.speaker: POISON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This white man is the cause of your suffering. This white man, his masters abroad -- and his black puppets in the government. Poison whips out a dog-eared manifesto from his army jack

dialogues.speaker: POISON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: FPoday Sankoh say -- resist and overthrow those who would exploit you! Shed their blood. He slaps Solomon's head with the book.

dialogues.speaker: POISON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Maybe some more digging will help you learn this lesson. The rope holding Solomon is cut. He falls to the ground a is prodded to his feet by several SOLDIERS holding Ak-47' Solomon looks down at the shovel. But doesn't move. Surreptitiously Archer glances at his watch. It is 5:59.

dialogues.speaker: POISON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Pick it up.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: Why? You are going to kill me anyway. With a sigh, Poison whispers in Solomon's ear:  168 93.

dialogues.speaker: POISON
dialogues.text: I do not need to kill you, Solomon Vandy. Because now you have a name. And a family. If you do not give me this diamond, I will find this family -- just as I have found your son. He goes to Dia and puts his arm around him.

dialogues.speaker: POISON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I will rape your wife in front of you, then slit her throat. (smiles) And I will keep your daughters for myself. It_is the first time we have seen the light go out of Solomon's eyes -- in part because of Poison's words, but mostly because of Dia's look of indifference.

dialogues.speaker: POISON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You think I am a devil. But only because I have lived in hell. I want to get out. You will help me. Curiously enough, these words could have been Archer's wh first we met him. He watches as: Solomon takes the shovel. All his hopes and dreams end he He is must dig the earth one last time to save his family He looks out at the jungle. Nothing looks familiar -- the trees SWIRLING...making him dizzy.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: I don't remember... Archer, head to the ground, watches Solomon closely. Snea another peek at his watch. 0600 hours. No air strike.

dialogues.speaker: POISON
dialogues.text: Find it! Or your family will die! As if sleep-walking,; Solomon begins to walk toward the p Poison and several armed rebels follow close behind.

dialogues.speaker: THE FIRST ROCKET EXPLODES 168
dialogues.text: in the middle of the camp -- sending a corrugated hut sky high. Everyone is knocked to the ground. An E.0. HELICOPTER GUNSHIP streaks by overhead. THE SECON ROCKET hits a truck -~ instantly turning it into a fireba

dialogues.speaker: THE GUNSHIP'S GATLING GUNS
dialogues.text: fire. 800 ROUNDS PER SECOND chew up everything in its pat  170

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER'S GUARD
dialogues.text: is almost cut in half by the devastating firepower. Arche rolls behind a tree -- CHUNKS FLY from its base.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON, CAPTAIN POISON AND AN R.U.F. GUARD
dialogues.text: have been knocked into a muddy DIAMOND PIT. Solomon hugs the ground as the jet SCREAMS over -- stitching the groun ARCHER gets to his feet and sprints toward Dia -- ignorin the EXPLOSIONS all around him. Since his hands are still tied behind his back --he hurtles a BODYCHECK into the ba of the SOLDIER guarding the boy. He THROWS HIMSELF on top of the boy -- as the gunships ma another pass -- KILLING R.U.F. soldiers who try to escape

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Solomon turns over the body of a dead guard and finds A MACHETE in his belt. Captain Poison looks up from the muc and reaches for his 9mm -- only it isn't in his holster. Frantically, he digs in the mud. It's nowhere to be found Solomon, meanwhile, gets to his feet and moves toward Poi who frantically tries to climb out of the pit -- The sides are high and slick. The closer Solomon gets, th more frantically Poison tries to claw his way out. But th walls are just too slippery... He FALLS back -- sliding down -- at last finding his gun. He raises it, but it's too late -- Solomon RAISES THE MAC All we can see is the lip of the pit, but we can HEAR Poi SCREAMS as Solomon's powerful arm RISES and FALLS. Solomon's face is contorted -- as the rage that has been buried for so long finds its expression. He brings the machete down again -- and again with all his might. Blood spattering him. Until he stops. With disbelief and horror at what he's done.

dialogues.speaker: TWO ARMORED VEHICLES 170
dialogues.text: appear with .50 caliber machine guns FIRING from their mo Behind them, MERCENARIES wearing the red beret of the E.O Joost organizes blocking positions around the perimeter o the village -- cutting down anyone who tries to escape. It is all over in a matter of minutes.  95.

dialogues.speaker: A SILENCE 17
dialogues.text: As the SMOKE and DUST clears, hardly a soul is moving. TH COLONEL strides into camp followed by TWO BODYGUARDS. ARCHER squints into the sun as the Colonel looms above hi

dialogues.speaker: THE COLONEL
dialogues.text: Thank you for calling in the location.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: You're welcome.

dialogues.speaker: THE COLONEL
dialogues.text: Then again, you had an ulterior motive, SOLOMON emerges from the pit, covered in blood. He isa terrifying sight -- this gentle man transformed into some kind of monster.

dialogues.speaker: THE COLONEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This must be the famous Mr. Vandy. (to Archer) Introduce us.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: This is Colonel Coetsee. He wants the diamond.

dialogues.speaker: THE COLONEL
dialogues.text: No more than you. Archer nods. True enough.

dialogues.speaker: THE COLONEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (calls out) Joost. Joost appears, holding a 9mm to Dia's head. Dia is shocke by his father's appearance.

dialogues.speaker: THE COLONEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (calls out) Lt. Gans. A mercenary LIEUTENANT appears.

dialogues.speaker: THE COLONEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You will organize the withdrawal. We move out in thirty minutes. (turns to Solomon) Let's take a walk, shall we? The Colonel's two bodyguards follow.  172 173 96.

dialogues.speaker: MOMENTS LATER
dialogues.text: are led at gunpoint into the diamond fields by the Colone BODYGUARDS. The Colonel and Joost follow behind with Dia.

dialogues.speaker: JOOST
dialogues.text: How much farther? Solomon doesn't answer. They pass one pit after another. A SAT-phone RINGS in the pack carried by one of the Colon bodyguards. The guard answers it and hands it to The Colo

dialogues.speaker: THE COLONEL
dialogues.text: (on the SAT-phone) eee eens No. ....No transport for prisoners....... Shoot them, that's what they pay us for.............. He hands the phone back to the bodyguard.

dialogues.speaker: HALF A MILE ON
dialogues.text: Solomon stops. The others react, expectant. Looming out of the thick growth is THE RUBBER TREE. Vines have covered its base, but it's definitely the same tree. Solomon measures the distance. Takes another few steps. He is about to raise the shovel. Then stops dead, the mus of his arm tensing. Inches from his foot, unmistakable -- is the TRIGGER of a land mine -- partially covered by vin Solomon glances back to Joost, who stands several yards a He doesn't see it. Solomon looks back at the trigger -- an idea forming. He turns in Archer's direction...

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: (looking around) An elephant graveyard.

dialogues.speaker: JOOST
dialogues.text: What? Keep digging. Archer knows Solomon is trying him something -- in code. Solomon carefully takes a step sideways. Sinks the shovel into the earth. Swallows. He's still in one piece. He sinks the shovel in again. And again. Digging. The Colonel watches, intently.  97. Solomon throws the shovel aside. Gets down on his knees, digging with his hands now. Faster. Scooping out dirt and rocks and sand. Until there is nothing left to scrape out He stares into the empty hole, confounded... He looks to Joost, then Archer, then back into the hole. Grabs the shovel again, starts digging the hole larger, w

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: It is not here ... it is not here!

dialogues.speaker: THE COLONEL
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: This is where I buried the stone. In this place. But it is not here! (beside himself) Someone has taken it! Come see for yourself! The Colonel motions Joost over to Solomon. Joost leaves D by the Colonel's side. As the mercenary ventures over -- Solomon glances at Archer, his eyes convey something. Arc reads the look. Out of the corner of his eye, he sees: The TRIGGER. It lies between Solomon's hole and Joost. Solomon tries desperately not to look at the trigger as J comes closer. Closer. Joost's boot HITS the TRIGGER. CLICK. A millisecond of realization on the stunned mercenary's face before-- THE EXPLOSION blows him to bits. Solomon is already DIVING behind a tree stump as-- Dia is thrown to the ground. Archer seizes the moment -- sending an OPEN-HAND STRIKE t the throat of his would-be executioner, then grabbing the 47, and shooting him before ripping the gun out of his ha

dialogues.speaker: STAY DOWN
dialogues.text: SOLOMON remains flattened behind the tree stump, head dow Archer sprays GUNFIRE at the mercenaries -- hitting the Colonel and the guards. He expends the entire clip. And no one is left standing  98. He looks back at the rebel camp -~ knowing that other mercenaries have heard the GUNFIRE.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let's go! Solomon gets up, orients himself and begins to count step Spears the shovel into the earth. Digs.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (admiringly) You lying bastard... Solomon throws the shovel down. THERE IN THE HOLE -- peeking out of the dirt -- is the to green cuff of a pantleg. Solomon digs it out with his han

dialogues.speaker: FAR OFF VOICES
dialogues.text: can be heard -- coming their way. Armed E.O. mercenaries. Archer rams a fresh clip into the machine gun, and reache into the dead bodyguard's pack for his SAT-phone. But as looks up, he sees --

dialogues.speaker: DIA
dialogues.text: holding The Colonel's 9mm. Aimed at him.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: Dia-- Dia's eyes flicker from Archer to Solomon and then back.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Dia, look at me. Dia looks into Solomon's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (in Mende) You are Dia Vandy. Of the proud Mende. Your mother loves you -~ and she waits by the fire making plaintains and red palm stew with your sister, N'yanda, and the new baby. (moves closer) The cows wait for you. And Babu the wild dog who minds no one but you. (moves closer still) And I am your father who loves you. And you will go home with me, and be my son. He walks right up to him, ignoring the gun, and wraps his ams around him.  174 99. Dia goes limp, the gun hangs loosely at his side -- as he allows himself to be held. BEHIND THEM, THE JUNG! PTS WITH Gi RE Solomon throws Dia to the ground. Archer takes cover.

dialogues.speaker: FOUR MERCENARIES ARE ADVANCING
dialogues.text: across the river -- firing as they come. Archer RETURNS FIRE, hitting two, The others hit the grou

dialogues.speaker: MOVE, MOVE, MOVE
dialogues.text: He SHOVES Solomon and Dia to their feet ANOTHER SPRAY OF GUNFIRE pins them down.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: When I start firing. You run! (stands up)

dialogues.speaker: -...- NOW
dialogues.text: He lays down COVERING FIRE -- as Solomon and Dia head for the brush. Archer waits until they are safe, then-- It's his turn to make a run. He takes off It's only thirty yards or so, but they seem an eternity. He is almost into the brush when--~ He is HIT in the back. He grunts and doubles over.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Fuck! He fights the shock and the pain -- adrenaline kicking in and stumbles into the dense cover.

dialogues.speaker: UP AHEAD
dialogues.text: He finds Solomon waiting. Solomon has no notion that Arch has been wounded.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: How far?

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: {through gritted teeth) There's...a strip...on a ridge... fifteen kilometers...south. Fawaz will meet us.....GOQ!........

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They take off in that direction.  175 176 177 100.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE JUNGLE
dialogues.text: An eerie quiet, broken only by the calls of exotic birds. Archer leads them --~ paying for every step. The entry wo in his back is small, almost unnoticeable. He stops and pulls out the SAT-phone. Dials.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: (on the SAT-phone) ...-Where are you? We're twelve clicks Out. ..... Two hours at most...

dialogues.speaker: FAWAZ, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: --You have it?

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: (on the SAT-phone) ...Roger that.

dialogues.speaker: FAWAZ, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Carrying a lot of fuel. Don't know if I can handle three more onboard. Archer looks up ahead to where Solomon and Dia are waitin

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: (on the SAT-phone) I'll get it sorted. He punches the button and starts off again.

dialogues.speaker: THREE KILOMETERS LATER 176
dialogues.text: Solomon is STARING at the bloody exit wound below Archer' arm pit -- the stain spreading. Archer sees him see it. Looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: You must sit.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Yeah, let's just have tea. He starts moving again.

dialogues.speaker: THREE KILOMETERS LATER 177
dialogues.text: Archer has to stop. His breathing is labored. He wipes hi mouth. Looks at his hand. No blood.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: Missed...the lung...but it's still....collapsed. Could... be....worse....I guess.  178 179 101.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: Rest now. They will not find us. Archer looks around. As if sensing their pursuit.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: They're good. (struggles to his feet) Let's go... He wills himself onward.

dialogues.speaker: THREE MORE KILOMETERS 178
dialogues.text: have taken their toll. Archer is stumbling now. Solomon says something to Dia in Mende.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: We will carry you.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: Yes. They each take one of Archer's arms over their shoulders. Yoked together, they struggle on.

dialogues.speaker: TWO KILOMETERS MORE 179
dialogues.text: And they have reached the base of a rocky ridge. Archer takes out the binoculars and sees--

dialogues.speaker: OFF IN THE DISTANCE
dialogues.text: TWO E.O. ARMORED VEHICLES churn up dust as they approach. Behind them come a squad of infantry on foot.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE SKY ABOVE
dialogues.text: The Cessna appears, circling.

dialogues.speaker: THE RIDGE ABOVE THEM IS VERY STEEP
dialogues.text: with dense brush blocking their way. In order to make it the landing strip, they will have to climb it. It would be difficult enough to climb on one's own, but t carry another man -- as Solomon tries as he hoists Archer over his shoulder -- is beyond imagining.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: No-- One step. Another step. And then another. Solomon's strength is tremendous. They make progress. Han ever hand. Rock by rock. Solomon's face contorts with the effort. His legs tremble but still he keeps going. The top of the ravine appears, far away, but tantalizingly in sight. For a moment we might even believe they will make it -- b then Solomon loses his footing. He stumbles. Archer is slammed to the ground, grunting in pain. Solomo reaches to pick him up again.

dialogues.speaker: STOP
dialogues.text: Archer's shirt-front is SOAKED in BLOOD. He is pale and gasping for breath. Solomon goes to pick him up again.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No. Let me...see it...

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: Mr. Archer--

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: You....want it all...for yourself. Solomon shakes his head, smiles ruefully. This is the mom he realizes Archer is not going to make it. He hands Archer the wrapped stone. Archer peels it open. Even wrapped in a dirty cloth, it takes the breath away - like something from the Gods.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It's real... He holds it up to the warm afternoon light.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So....beautiful. Archer looks up to see Solomon staring at him. He wraps i back in the cloth.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: I thought you would steal it from me.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHER
dialogues.text: It occurred to me. Solomon smiles.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: To me, as well,

dialogues.speaker: UP ABOVE 180
dialogues.text: The plane touches down.

dialogues.speaker: DOWN BELOW 181
dialogues.text: The Armored Cars are getting closer.
